chunks.original_text: 男之气属阳，女之气属阴，阴阳二气交度，男女魂魄，即居于其间。 魂为阳神如日，魄为阴神如月，魂魄互为室宅。 魂属性，主处内，立置鄞鄂之密室； 魄属精，主营外，筑垣城郭之外宅。 鄞鄂如内之五脏六腑，城郭如外之四肢百骸。 城郭完全，而人物方能安居于内。 爰此阴阳交度之时，男女以情相合，如乾上坤下。 乾坤相配，乾动而直，气布精流； 坤静而翕，为道之舍庐。 在男刚道，一施而退； 在女柔道，化而滋生。 阴阳上气，凝而成象，胎元已结。 九者金之数，七者火之数，八者木之数，六者水之数。 九还七返，八归六居，金木水火之气，皆入胎中。 九还七返，八归六居，与逆用还返之义不同。 此返还，乃男女阴阳之气，返归于胎中，自外入内之说。 盖男之精白，属金； 女之血赤，属火。 金火之气相拘，抟聚一处，金中有水之气，火中有木之气，则水定火。 火去炼金，水去济火，木去生火，金去生水，金木水火，自相熏蒸，其中变化，自有真土，此五行所生之初也。 胎中虽是五行变化，当阴阳交度之际，暗中即有一点先天造化入内，而先生水。 这个水，乃先天先地而生，清而无瑕。 为道之形象，真乙难图，至无而含至有，至虚而含至实。 男女精血，非此水亦不能为工。 是水也，无形而能生形，是以变化不测，一变为水而生肾，二变为火而生心，王变为木而生肝，四变为金而生肺，五变为土而生脾。 变而分布，独居一方。 然虽独居一方，而五行之气，仍聚一处，类如鸡子，白黑相符。 黑为阴，白为阳，阴阳符合，一气浑含，故曰纵横一寸，以为始初。 始初者，根本也，一气为根本。 根本立，则枝干自发，故曰“四肢五脏，筋骨乃俱。 ”言四肢五脏筋骨，皆自一气变化而成全也。 弥历十月，气足形全，脱出其胞，骨弱可卷，肉滑如铅。 此生人之道则然。 若人审明此生身之理，调和吾身真阴真阳，逆而修之，仍了胎中之一息，结为圣胎，温养十月，身外有身，造化由我，可以却死，可以延生矣。 噫！ 逆则成仙之道，固不易知。 而顺则生人之道，亦难以晓。 若知生人之道，而颠倒之间，即是成仙之道。 奈何人不审思生人之道，而妄想学仙，岂不可叹乎？ 坎男为月，离女为日，日以施德，月以舒光，月受日化，体不亏伤。 阳失其契，阴侵其明，晦朔薄蚀，掩冒相倾，阳消其形，阴凌灾生。 男女相胥，含吐以滋，雌雄错杂，以类相求。 金化为水，水性周章，火化为土，水不得行。 男动外施，女静内藏，溢度过节，为女所拘。 魄以钤魂，不得淫奢。 不寒不暑，进退合时，各得其和，俱吐证符。 上节言生人之道，系阴阳相合而成。 此节乃推广其类，而证修仙之道，非阴阳相合，灵胎不结也。 如坎卦为男，其体阴，象月。 离卦为女，其体阳，象日。 月本黑体，纯阴无阳，借日生光，每月晦尽朔初，与日一会。 日以施德，月以舒光，是月受日化，而黑体得以生明，乃不亏伤也，此日月以时而交则然。 若日与月失其契合常道，阴错阳差，月之阴气，侵伤日体，晦朔月蚀，掩其光辉，阳消其形，阴凌而灾生矣。 盖日道月道，交斜而行。 当交之时，日在下，月在上，日景射月，而月生明。 若南北同度，东西同度，其体相对，掩冒其光，阴阳相争而不和，在朔则为日蚀，在望则为月蚀。
chunks.translated_text:
The male’s qi pertains to yang, the female’s qi pertains to yin. When the two qi of yin and yang intermingle, the hun and po of male and female reside therein. The hun is the yang spirit, like the sun; the po is the yin spirit, like the moon. Hun and po serve as each other’s dwelling. The hun pertains to nature, governing the interior, establishing the inner chamber of yin and yang; the po pertains to essence, governing the exterior, constructing the outer residence beyond the city walls. The inner chamber is like the five viscera and six bowels within, while the city walls are like the four limbs and hundred bones without. Only when the city walls are complete can beings securely dwell within.

At the moment when yin and yang intermingle, male and female unite through emotion, like Qian above and Kun below. Qian and Kun pair together: Qian moves and extends, its qi spreading and essence flowing; Kun is still and receptive, serving as the abode of the Dao. In the male, the firm Dao emits and withdraws; in the female, the yielding Dao transforms and engenders. The ascending qi of yin and yang congeals into form, and the embryo’s origin is knotted. Nine is the number of metal, seven the number of fire, eight the number of wood, and six the number of water. Nine returns, seven reverts; eight returns, six resides. The qi of metal, wood, water, and fire all enter the embryo. This returning and reverting differs from the reverse application of cyclical return. Here, the returning refers to the qi of male and female yin and yang reverting into the embryo, an inward movement from without.

Now, the male’s essence is white, pertaining to metal; the female’s blood is red, pertaining to fire. When the qi of metal and fire constrain each other, coalescing in one place, within metal resides the qi of water, and within fire resides the qi of wood. Thus, water stabilizes fire, fire refines metal, water nourishes fire, wood engenders fire, and metal engenders water. Metal, wood, water, and fire mutually steam and transform, wherein true earth naturally arises—this is the origin of the five phases. Though the embryo undergoes the transformations of the five phases, at the moment when yin and yang intermingle, a point of primordial creation silently enters within, first engendering water. This water, born prior to heaven and earth, is pure and flawless. It is the form of the Dao, the true One difficult to depict, containing utmost being within utmost non-being, and utmost fullness within utmost emptiness. Without this water, the essence and blood of male and female cannot accomplish their work.

This water, though formless, can generate form. Thus, its transformations are unfathomable: first it transforms into water to engender the kidneys, second into fire to engender the heart, third into wood to engender the liver, fourth into metal to engender the lungs, and fifth into earth to engender the spleen. Having transformed and distributed, each resides in its own domain. Yet though each resides in its own domain, the qi of the five phases still gather in one place, resembling an egg where white and black correspond. The black is yin, the white is yang; yin and yang correspond, a single qi contained in unity. Thus it is said: “Vertically and horizontally, one inch marks the beginning.” The beginning is the root; the single qi is the root. Once the root is established, branches and trunk naturally arise. Hence it is said: “The four limbs and five viscera, sinews and bones, are all complete.” This means the four limbs, five viscera, sinews, and bones all form through the transformations of this single qi.

After ten months, the qi is full and the form complete. Emerging from the womb, the bones are soft and pliable, the flesh smooth as lead. Such is the Dao of human birth. If one clearly understands this principle of bodily generation, harmonizes the true yin and true yang within, and reverses the process to cultivate it, one can grasp the single breath within the embryo, congeal it into a sacred embryo, nurture it for ten months, and attain a body beyond the body. Creation then lies within one’s own hands, allowing one to defer death and extend life.

Alas! The Dao of becoming an immortal through reversal is not easily known, yet even the Dao of human birth through natural sequence is difficult to comprehend. If one understands the Dao of human birth, then its inversion is precisely the Dao of becoming an immortal. How lamentable that people do not carefully consider the Dao of human birth yet vainly aspire to learn immortality!

Kan male is the moon, Li female is the sun. The sun bestows its virtue, the moon unfurls its light. The moon receives the sun’s transformation, its body unharmed. If yang loses its harmony, yin encroaches upon its brightness. At the dark and new moons, eclipses occur, obscuring and overwhelming each other. Yang’s form diminishes, yin’s encroachment brings calamity. Male and female mutually assist, inhaling and exhaling to nourish. Female and male intermingle, seeking their kind. Metal transforms into water, whose nature flows freely; fire transforms into earth, blocking water’s movement. The male moves and emits outwardly, the female is still and stores inwardly. If emission exceeds moderation, it is constrained by the female. The po restrains the hun, preventing excess. Neither cold nor hot, advancing and retreating in timely measure, each attains harmony and together they manifest confirmation.

The preceding section spoke of the Dao of human birth, which arises through the union of yin and yang. This section expands upon its kind to demonstrate the Dao of immortal cultivation: without the union of yin and yang, the numinous embryo cannot form. Kan trigram represents the male, its body yin, symbolizing the moon. Li trigram represents the female, its body yang, symbolizing the sun. The moon’s body is inherently dark, purely yin without yang. Borrowing the sun’s light, at the end of the lunar month and beginning of the new moon, it meets the sun. The sun bestows its virtue, the moon unfurls its light; the moon receives the sun’s transformation, and its dark body gains brightness without harm. Such is the timely union of sun and moon. If the sun and moon lose their harmonious constant Dao, yin and yang misalign, the moon’s yin qi injures the sun’s body, and at the dark and new moons, eclipses occur, obscuring its brilliance. Yang’s form diminishes, yin’s encroachment brings calamity.

Now, the paths of the sun and moon cross obliquely. At the time of crossing, the sun is below and the moon above; the sun’s rays illuminate the moon, giving it brightness. If they align in the same north-south or east-west degree, their bodies oppose each other, obscuring each other’s light. Yin and yang contend without harmony: at the new moon, a solar eclipse occurs; at the full moon, a lunar eclipse.

Now, the body one receives is fundamentally Non-Being. It is through the union of an ordinary father and mother, the commingling of male and female, that original essence and original qi take their initial lodging, arising from Non-Being into Being.

chunks.original_text: 日蚀者，阴掩其阳也。 月蚀者，阳掩其阴也。 日蚀月蚀，二者皆阴阳过胜之故。 又如男女相胥，一含一吐，而能滋种。 凡物雌雄错乱，同类相交，而方孕族。 此皆阴阳相交，生生不息之道。 又如金化为水，水性周流，不息而成章； 火化为土，土厚壅积，塞滞其水，而水不得行。 又如男主动而外施，女主静而内藏。 若男贪女色，淫欲过度，交合过节，失其男动之本体，男反为女所拘制。 此二者，阴阳和而不和，生中带杀，反生其灾矣。 即此以观，则知阴阳贵于和合，尤贵于和合得其中正。 得其中正，为真阴真阳； 不得中正，为假阴假阳。 真假之分，只在中正与不中正之间耳。 修道者，用魄之真情，所以铃魂之灵性也。 魄即道心，真知之刚情； 魂即人心，灵知之柔性。 柔性主进退而少裁制，遇物留连，见景生情，刚情多果断而有主宰。 魄以铃魂，以情之刚，铃性之柔，则人心静而道心彰。 性情相合，刚柔一气矣。 然虽以道心制人心，得其人心柔顺即已。 若制之太过，常以人心为事，则必道心又昧，明极反暗； 道心中，人心乘间而生，性情乖戾，吉化为凶，故曰不得淫奢也。 不寒不暑者，性不乱而情不迷，勿忘勿助之功。 进退合时者，闲其邪而存其诚，执中用权之道，大小无伤，两圆俱全，各得其和，无损于彼，有益于我。 性情吐真， 阴阳混成，证于日月合符行中之道矣。 关关雎鸠，在河之洲，窈窕淑女，君子好逑。 雄不独处，雌不孤居。 玄武龟蛇，蟠蚪相扶，以明牝牡，意当相须。 假使二女共室，颜色甚姝，令苏秦通言，张仪合媒，发辩利舌，奋舒美辞，推心调谐，合为夫妻，弊发腐齿，终不相知。 若药物非种，名类不同，分刻参差，失其纲纪，虽黄帝临炉，太乙执火，八公铸炼，淮南调合，立宇崇坛，玉为阶陛，麟脯凤脂，把籍长跪，祷祝神祗，请哀诸鬼，沐浴斋戒，冀有所望； 亦犹和胶补釜，以硇涂疮，去冷加冰，除热用汤，飞龟舞蛇，愈见乖张。 上节言阴阳相当，进退合时，方能修道有功。 此节言孤阴寡阳，一切非类之弊，使人晓悟，改邪归正耳。 易曰：“一阴一阳之谓道。 ”盖以有阴有阳，阴阳相合，方谓道。 孤阴寡阳，阴阳各偏，不谓道。 故宣圣删诗，而以关雎之篇为首者，将示其君子之道，造端乎夫妇也。 夫妇之道，即阴阳造化之道。 凡天地间，有情无情之物，牝者皆属阴，为雌为妇； 牡者皆属阳，为雄为夫。 一牝一牡，一雌一雄，一妇一夫，一阴一阳，彼此相须，方有造化。 在人男女同居而生育，在物龟蛇蟠纠而孕种。 举此二者，则牝牡相须，雌雄相合之理，可以类推而知。 假使二女同室，颜色甚姝，结为夫妻，岂能相知而生育？ 此理之显而易见者。 世间修道盲汉，不知阴阳配合之理，牝牡相须之道，舍自己真阴真阳性命之根，而求身外与我种类不同之物。 或流而为采战，或误认为炉火，或立坛而拜斗朝真，或斋戒而请哀诸鬼，冀望延年长寿，长生不死，亦犹和胶补釜，以硇涂疮，去冷加冰，除热用汤。 是犹龟飞蛇舞，龟焉能飞，蛇焉能舞，岂不愈见乖张乎仙翁此节，首提关雎龟蛇，牝牡相须之理，次以非类不同，开示后学，可谓慈悲之至。 一切盲汉可以悟矣。
chunks.translated_text:
A solar eclipse occurs when yin obscures yang. A lunar eclipse occurs when yang obscures yin. Both solar and lunar eclipses arise from the excessive dominance of either yin or yang.

Just as man and woman mutually engage—one inhaling, one exhaling—to propagate offspring, all things, when male and female intermingle and like kinds unite, then breed and multiply. This is the Dao of yin and yang in ceaseless generation.

Consider how metal transforms into water: water’s nature flows without cease, forming patterns. Fire transforms into earth: earth, thick and clogged, obstructs water’s passage, preventing its flow.

The male governs movement and external expression; the female governs stillness and internal containment. If a man indulges in lust, his desires become excessive, his unions untimely, and he loses his fundamental male dynamism—then the male is instead constrained by the female.

In both cases, yin and yang appear harmonious yet are not; life carries within it destruction, and calamity arises instead. From this, we see that the harmony of yin and yang is precious, and even more precious is harmony that attains the central equilibrium.

Attaining the central equilibrium yields true yin and true yang; failing to attain it yields false yin and false yang. The distinction between true and false lies solely in whether or not the center is held.

The cultivator of the Dao employs the true essence of the *po* to restrain the numinous nature of the *hun*. The *po* is the Dao-mind, the resolute essence of true knowing; the *hun* is the human mind, the pliable nature of numinous knowing. The pliable nature governs advance and retreat yet lacks restraint; it lingers upon encountering things and generates emotions at the sight of scenes. The resolute essence is decisive and self-governing.

Using the *po* to restrain the *hun*—applying the resoluteness of essence to temper the pliability of nature—still the human mind, and the Dao-mind becomes manifest. When essence and nature unite, firmness and softness merge into one *qi*.

Yet though the Dao-mind governs the human mind, one must attain the human mind’s compliance and no more. If one over-controls, constantly treating the human mind as an object, the Dao-mind will dim, and extreme clarity will revert to darkness. Within the Dao-mind, the human mind seizes the opportunity to arise; essence and nature become discordant, fortune transforms into misfortune. Thus, one must avoid excess.

Neither cold nor hot—nature remains unconfused, essence unbewildered—this is the effort of neither forgetting nor forcing. Advancing and retreating in timely measure—warding off the deviant while preserving sincerity—this is the Dao of holding the center and employing adaptability. Neither great nor small is harmed; both circles remain whole, each attaining harmony, neither diminishing the other, both benefiting oneself.

When essence and nature express truth, yin and yang merge into oneness, and one realizes the Dao of the sun and moon’s harmonious movement.

*Guan guan* cry the ospreys,
on the islet in the river.
Graceful and refined is the maiden,
the noble man’s fine match.

The male does not dwell alone; the female does not live in solitude. The Dark Warrior’s tortoise and snake coil together, demonstrating the mutual necessity of male and female.

Suppose two women share a chamber, their beauty most fair. Let Su Qin convey their words, Zhang Yi arrange their match, eloquent tongues unleashed, splendid words deployed, hearts laid bare in harmony, and a union as husband and wife proposed. Yet though their hair may wither and teeth decay, they will never truly know one another.

If medicinal substances are not of the same kind, their categories differ, their proportions misaligned, their principles lost—even if the Yellow Emperor tends the furnace, Tai Yi wields the fire, the Eight Lords refine the elixir, Huainan harmonizes the blend, a towering altar is raised, jade steps laid, unicorn flesh and phoenix fat offered, registers held in reverence, spirits and gods entreated, ghosts supplicated, ablutions and purification rites performed, and hopes pinned on success—it is like using glue to mend a cauldron, sal ammoniac to treat a wound, adding ice to dispel cold, or hot water to relieve heat. Flying tortoises and dancing snakes only reveal greater absurdity.

The preceding section spoke of yin and yang in proper balance, advancing and retreating in timely measure, enabling successful Dao cultivation. This section exposes the folly of solitary yin or solitary yang and all mismatched unions, awakening people to abandon error and return to correctness.

The *Yijing* states: “The Dao consists of one yin and one yang.” Only with both yin and yang, united in harmony, can it be called the Dao. Solitary yin or solitary yang, each biased and incomplete, cannot be called the Dao.

Thus, when the Sage Confucius edited the *Book of Songs*, he placed the “Guan Ju” at the beginning to demonstrate the noble man’s Dao, which begins with the union of husband and wife. The Dao of husband and wife is the Dao of yin and yang’s creative transformation.

In all things between heaven and earth, whether endowed with feeling or not, the female belongs to yin—she is the hen, the wife; the male belongs to yang—he is the rooster, the husband. One female and one male, one hen and one rooster, one wife and one husband, one yin and one yang—only when they mutually engage does creation occur.

In humans, man and woman cohabit to bear children; in creatures, tortoise and snake coil to conceive offspring. From these two examples, the principle of female and male’s mutual necessity, hen and rooster’s union, can be inferred and understood.

Suppose two women share a chamber, their beauty most fair, and form a union as husband and wife—how could they know one another and bear children? This principle is evident and easily seen.

Yet in the world, blind fools pursuing the Dao do not understand the principle of yin and yang’s union, the Dao of female and male’s mutual necessity. They abandon the root of their own true yin and true yang’s life and seek outside themselves things of a different kind.

Some degenerate into sexual arts, others mistakenly practice furnace and fire, erect altars to worship the Dipper and pay homage to immortals, or perform purification rites to supplicate ghosts and spirits, hoping for longevity and eternal life. This is like using glue to mend a cauldron, sal ammoniac to treat a wound, adding ice to dispel cold, or hot water to relieve heat—like tortoises flying and snakes dancing. How could tortoises fly or snakes dance? Does this not reveal even greater absurdity?

In this section, the Immortal Elder first presents the “Guan Ju” and the tortoise and snake, illustrating the principle of female and male’s mutual necessity, then uses mismatched unions to instruct later learners. His compassion is boundless. All blind fools may now awaken.

If they align in the same north-south or east-west degree, their bodies oppose each other, obscuring each other’s light. Yin and yang contend without harmony: at the new moon, a solar eclipse occurs; at the full moon, a lunar eclipse.

chunks.original_text: 上德无为，不以察求。 下德为之，其用不休。 知白守黑，神明自来，白者金精，黑者水基。 水者道枢，去数名一。 阴阳之始，玄含黄芽。 五金之主，北方河车。 故铅外黑，内怀金华，被褐怀玉，外为狂夫。 金为水母，母隐子胎。 水为金子，子藏母胞。 真人至妙，若有若无。 仿佛太渊，乍沉乍浮。 退尔分布，各守境隅。 采之类白，造之则朱。 炼为表卫，白里真居。 方圆径寸，混而相拘。 先天地生，巍巍尊高。 旁有垣阙，状似蓬壶。 环匝关闭，四通踟蹰。 守御密固，阏绝奸邪。 曲阁相通，以戒不虞。 可以无思，难以愁劳。 神炁满室，莫之能留。 守之者昌，失之者亡。 动静休息，常与人俱。 上节言修道必须寻同类有情之物方能济事。 若非其类，万无一成。 但修道有二法：一以道全形之事，一以术延命之事。 上德者，以道全其形，抱元守一，行无为之道，即可了事。 故曰上德无为，不以察求也。 下德者，以术延其命，由勉抵安，行有为之道，方能还元。 故曰下德为之，其用不休也。 夫上德之所以不察求者，以其上德之人，天真未伤，客气未入。 若顿悟本性，无修无证，直超彼岸，察求之功无所用。 下德之所以用不休者，以其天真已亏，知识已开，虽能顿悟本性，不能斩然驯顺，必用渐修之道，增减之功。 增而又增，减而又减，直至无可增减。 义精仁熟，方到休息之处，此不休之用所由贵也。 上德下德，身份不一，故其用亦异。 若下德者，到义精仁熟时，亦与上德者，同归一途也。 所谓或安而行之，或利而行之，或勉强而行之，及其成功之一也。 试明下德其用不休之旨，不休之用，即后天中返先天之道。 后天中返先天，即知白守黑之道。 白者，莹净道心也。 黑者，晦暗人心也。 知其白，则道心实； 守其黑，则人心虚。 道心实，则真知常存； 人心虚，则灵知不正。 真知灵知两而合一，刚柔相配。 其中恍惚有象，杳冥有精，而神明自来矣。 神明即先天真一之气，又名先天真一之精，又名谷神。 谷神乃阴阳二气混合之神。 阴阳分散，此神晦暗，其体黑而失其明，如神明去矣。 阴阳相合，此神莹净，其体白而复其明，如神明来矣。 故曰知白守黑，神明自来。 何谓白者金精，黑者水基？ 盖道心所具之真知为真情，其德原自刚健，为乾家之物，取象为金精。 人心所藏之灵知，为真性，其德本来柔顺，为坤家之物，取象为水基。 灵知本不属水而属火，因其灵知藏于人心，能守其人心之黑，则人心虚极静笃。 灵知柔顺，邪火消灭，与真知恍惚中相连，杳冥中有变，和气熏蒸，而生真一之水，是黑为水之基耳。 夫水者，天一所生，乃道之枢纽，为五金之主，阴阳之本，内含黄芽，有北方河车之正气。 何以知之？ 人心灵知虚静，客气不来； 道心真知发现，生气复还，如草木在地中萌芽，其色黄嫩，其质纯水，故名黄芽。 因其阳气以水而上升，又名河车； 因其阳气自阴中生出，又名神明，其实黄芽、河车、神明，皆形容道心真知，一点刚健之正气耳。 比象黑铅，外黑内白，内怀金华，又如被褐怀玉，外为狂夫也。 人自先天交于后天，妄情生欲水，金为水母也。 后天中返先天，黑中有白，精一之水，又生真知之真情，而母反隐于子胎，是水反生金矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The highest virtue acts without striving, not through discerning pursuit.
The lesser virtue labors ceaselessly, its application unending.

Know the white, guard the black—spiritual illumination will come of itself.
The white is the essence of metal; the black, the foundation of water.
Water is the pivot of the Dao, beyond number named as the One.
The origin of yin and yang, it holds the yellow sprout within the mysterious.
Lord of the five metals, the river chariot of the north.
Thus lead appears black without, yet harbors golden radiance within—
clad in coarse cloth while bearing jade, outwardly a madman.

Metal is the mother of water; the mother conceals herself in the child’s womb.
Water is the child of metal; the child shelters itself in the mother’s womb.
The perfected person is most subtle, now present, now absent—
like the great abyss, now sinking, now floating.
Withdraw and distribute, each guarding its own domain.
Gather it and it resembles white; refine it and it becomes vermilion.
Tempered into protective armor, the true dwells within the white.
Round or square, a mere inch in diameter, blended yet mutually constrained.
Born before heaven and earth, majestic and exalted.
Surrounded by walls and gates, resembling Penglai’s isle.
Encircled and sealed, four pathways hesitate.
Guard it with utmost secrecy, blocking all deceit and evil.
Curved corridors connect, to ward against the unforeseen.
One may be free from thought, yet not from care and toil.
The chamber fills with spirit and qi—none can detain it.
Those who preserve it flourish; those who lose it perish.
In movement and stillness, rest and activity, it ever accompanies the person.

The preceding section spoke of cultivating the Dao by seeking beings of the same kind—without this, nothing can be accomplished. Yet there are two methods of cultivation: one preserves the form through the Dao, the other extends life through technique. The highest virtue preserves form through the Dao, embracing the origin and guarding the One, practicing the Way of non-action—thus the matter is resolved. Hence it is said: *The highest virtue acts without striving, not through discerning pursuit.* The lesser virtue extends life through technique, progressing from effort to ease, practicing the Way of action—only thus can the origin be restored. Hence it is said: *The lesser virtue labors ceaselessly, its application unending.*

Why does the highest virtue not pursue discernment? Because those of highest virtue retain their celestial purity, untouched by guest qi. If they suddenly awaken to their original nature, without cultivation or verification, they transcend directly to the other shore—no discerning pursuit is needed. Why does the lesser virtue never cease its application? Because their celestial purity is already diminished, their knowledge already awakened. Though they may suddenly awaken to their original nature, they cannot immediately attain docility; they must employ gradual cultivation, the work of augmentation and reduction. Augmenting again and again, reducing again and again, until nothing remains to augment or reduce. Only when righteousness is refined and benevolence matured do they reach the place of rest—hence the value of ceaseless application.

The highest and lesser virtues differ in their capacities, thus their methods diverge. Yet when those of lesser virtue refine righteousness and mature benevolence, they too merge onto the same path as the highest. As it is said: *Whether acting in ease, for profit, or through effort, their success is one.*

To clarify the ceaseless application of the lesser virtue: this ceaseless application is the Way of returning from the postnatal to the prenatal. Returning from the postnatal to the prenatal is the Way of knowing the white and guarding the black. The white is the luminous purity of the Dao-mind; the black, the obscured darkness of the human mind. Knowing the white, the Dao-mind becomes substantial; guarding the black, the human mind becomes empty. When the Dao-mind is substantial, true knowing abides; when the human mind is empty, spiritual knowing is not misled. True knowing and spiritual knowing unite as one, hardness and softness harmonize. Within this state, indistinct forms appear, and in the profound darkness, essence emerges—spiritual illumination comes of itself.

Spiritual illumination is the prenatal true qi of the One, also called the prenatal true essence of the One, or the Valley Spirit. The Valley Spirit is the spirit of blended yin and yang qi. When yin and yang disperse, this spirit darkens, its body black and bereft of light—spiritual illumination departs. When yin and yang unite, this spirit becomes luminous, its body white and radiant—spiritual illumination returns. Hence it is said: *Know the white, guard the black—spiritual illumination will come of itself.*

What is meant by *the white is the essence of metal; the black, the foundation of water*? The true knowing possessed by the Dao-mind is true essence, its virtue originally firm and strong, belonging to the Qian trigram—symbolized as the essence of metal. The spiritual knowing stored in the human mind is true nature, its virtue originally soft and compliant, belonging to the Kun trigram—symbolized as the foundation of water. Spiritual knowing does not inherently belong to water but to fire; yet because it resides in the human mind, guarding the black of the human mind empties and stills it. Spiritual knowing becomes compliant, the deviant fire vanishes, and in the indistinct it connects with true knowing. In the profound darkness, transformation occurs, harmonious qi steams and rises, giving birth to the true water of the One—thus the black is the foundation of water.

Water, born of Heavenly One, is the pivot of the Dao, lord of the five metals, root of yin and yang, containing the yellow sprout within. It possesses the upright qi of the northern river chariot. How is this known? When the human mind’s spiritual knowing is empty and still, guest qi does not intrude; when the Dao-mind’s true knowing manifests, vital qi returns—like grasses and trees sprouting in the earth, their color tender yellow, their substance pure water—hence the name *yellow sprout*. Because yang qi ascends with water, it is also called *river chariot*; because yang qi emerges from yin, it is also called *spiritual illumination*. In truth, the yellow sprout, river chariot, and spiritual illumination all describe the Dao-mind’s true knowing—a single upright qi of firm strength. It is likened to black lead, black without yet white within, harboring golden radiance—like one clad in coarse cloth bearing jade, outwardly a madman.

Since the prenatal descends into the postnatal, false emotions give rise to the water of desire—metal is the mother of water. Yet in returning from the postnatal to the prenatal, within the black there is white. The water of essence and the One gives birth to the true essence of true knowing, and the mother conceals herself in the child’s womb—thus water in turn generates metal.

chunks.original_text: 精一之水，又借真情而生，水为金之子，先天中运后天真情之金，生精一之水，而子又藏子母胞，是金又生水矣。 金生水者，顺其所欲，所以诱彼之欢心，后天而奉天时也。 水生金者，逆运其机，所以固我之命宝，先天而天弗违也。 金水互生，顺逆两用，彼我无伤，而真人生于其间矣。 真人，即上所渭神明，又曰圣胎，乃先天虚无真一之气，凝结而成象者。 这个真人，至神至妙，非色非空，即色即空。 乍沉者，寂然不动也； 乍浮者，感而遂通也。 色空不拘，动静自然，至无而含至有，至虚而含至实，阴阳五行之气，无不俱备。 故曰退而分布，各守境隅。 当圣胎凝结，真人有象，五元五德，混然一气； 五物五贼，各守境隅。 不但不能害道，而且有以助道。 采之类白者，始而虚室生白，圣胎凝结也。 造之则朱者，既而以火炼金，圣胎坚固也。 炼为表卫者，外丹成就也。 白里真居者，内丹圆明也。 方圆径寸者，外圆内方，而内外一气。 混而相拘者，神凝气聚，而神气混合，内外如一。 神气混合，一灵妙有，法界圆通。 先天地生，巍巍尊高，造化不得而拘，万物不得而屈，入于真空无碍，浑然一中之境，故曰状似蓬壶也。 到此地位，圆陀陀．光灼灼，良知良能，复见娘生本来面目。 原本到手，须当防危虑险，固济牢封，放曰旁有垣阙也。 环匝关闭，四通踟蹰者，所以防外患，外物不入也。 守御密固，阏绝奸邪者，所以除内贼，内念不出也。 曲阁相通，以戒不虞者，戒慎乎其所不睹，恐惧乎其所不闻。 无隐不照，无微不入，如曲阁相通，幽明如一，不使有丝毫邪气留于方寸之中也。 可以无思，难以愁劳者，有用用中无用，无功功里施功，非有愁劳强作。 但只无思无为，精一执中而已。 以上警戒法语，是欲学者，临时谨慎，不容稍有懈怠，自取咎吝耳。 盖圣胎凝结，神气充足，阳极必阴，易于致凶。 守之则十月胎全丹热而昌，失之则霎时气收神飞而亡。 故圣人于此，任火停轮。 用阴符之道，刚以柔济，一动一静，一休一息，常与道俱，弃有为而入无为，由了命而后了性，在末生身处下功夫也。 此下德为之，其用不休，由勉强而归自然之道。 到得自然之处，与上德者，同是一事。 以上言命理，以下言性理，学者着意。 内以养己，安静虚无。 原本隐明，内照形躯。 闭塞其兑，筑固灵株。 三光陆沉，温养子珠，视之不见，近而易求。 勤而行之，夙夜不休。 伏食三载，轻举远游。 跨火不焦，入水不濡。 能存能亡，长乐无忧。 道成德就，潜伏俟时。 太乙乃召，移居中州。 功满上升，膺箓受图。 修真之道，性命必须双修，功夫还要两段。 外药所以了命，内药所以了性。 外药者外夺造化，以复先天； 内药者内保本真，以化后天。 先天所以脱幻身，后天所以脱法身。 世间迷人，不知圣贤立言妙义，误认外药为炉火，内药为孤修。 殊不知先天真阳，从虚无中来，乃属于彼，故谓外药。 先天既来，归根复命，即属于我，故谓内药。 内外之分，性命之界，两者同出而异名，同谓之元之又元。 节首提出内以养己，则内外之理昭昭矣。 正合篇首将欲养性，延命却期之旨。 己者，性也。 当金丹成就，命基已固，急须修性以脱法身。
chunks.translated_text:
The water of essence and the One is further born through true emotion. Water is the child of metal, yet within the prenatal, the metal of postnatal true emotion circulates to generate the water of essence and the One, and the child in turn conceals the womb of child and mother—thus metal again gives birth to water.

That metal gives birth to water follows desire’s course to entice the other’s joy, serving the postnatal to accord with Heaven’s timing. That water gives birth to metal reverses the mechanism’s operation to secure my life-treasure, serving the prenatal so that Heaven does not oppose it. With metal and water mutually generating, both forward and reverse are employed, neither self nor other harmed, and the true person arises between them.

The true person—this is the *spiritual illumination* mentioned above, also called the *sacred embryo*—is the prenatal’s empty-none true One qi, coagulated into form. This true person is most divine and wondrous, neither form nor emptiness, yet both form and emptiness. When sinking, it is still and unmoving; when rising, it responds and instantly pervades. Unbound by form or emptiness, moving or still in spontaneity, it contains utmost nonbeing within utmost being, utmost emptiness within utmost fullness. The qi of yin-yang and the Five Agents is all complete within it. Thus it is said: when withdrawing, it disperses and each guards its domain.

When the sacred embryo coagulates and the true person takes form, the Five Primes and Five Powers merge into a single qi; the Five Substances and Five Thieves each guard their domains. Not only can they not harm the Dao, but they even assist it. The white of lead’s kind, at first the empty chamber generating whiteness, is the sacred embryo’s coagulation. Refining it into vermilion is the sacred embryo’s firmness through fire-forging. Refining it into external defense is the external elixir’s accomplishment. The true dwelling within whiteness is the internal elixir’s perfect clarity. A square inch in diameter, externally round and internally square, yet internally and externally one qi. Blended and mutually bound, spirit congeals and qi gathers, spirit and qi merging so that inner and outer become as one.

With spirit and qi merged, a single numinous wondrous being, the dharma-realm is perfectly pervaded. Born before Heaven and Earth, majestic and exalted, beyond the constraints of creation and the subjugation of the myriad things, it enters the unobstructed true emptiness, the utterly unified central realm—thus it is said to resemble Penglai. At this stage, round and luminous, radiant and resplendent, innate knowledge and innate capacity are restored, and one sees the original face from birth. The original root in hand, one must guard against danger and peril, firmly seal and secure it—hence it is said to be surrounded by walls and gates.

Encircled and sealed, with fourfold thoroughfares and hesitation, is to guard against external calamities so that external things do not enter. Defense is tightly secured, blocking and cutting off treacherous evil, to eliminate internal thieves so that internal thoughts do not escape. Interconnected winding chambers, to guard against the unforeseen, are vigilance where nothing is seen and fear where nothing is heard. Nothing is hidden from illumination, nothing too subtle to enter—like interconnected winding chambers, darkness and light as one, allowing not a trace of evil qi to remain within the square inch of the heart.

One may be without thought, but not with anxious toil—there is activity within non-activity, achievement within non-achievement, not through forced toil. Simply be without thought or action, holding fast to the One and centeredness. The above admonitions are for the practitioner to be vigilant in the moment, permitting no slackening to incur fault and misfortune.

For when the sacred embryo coagulates and spirit and qi are abundant, yang at its extreme must turn to yin, easily inviting misfortune. Guard it, and the ten-month embryo is complete, the elixir ripe, and one flourishes; lose it, and in an instant qi withdraws, spirit flees, and one perishes. Thus the sage at this stage halts the fire and stills the wheel, employing the Dao of the *Yin Fu*, balancing hardness with softness. In every movement and stillness, every rest and breath, one constantly accompanies the Dao, abandoning effortful action to enter effortless action, first completing life before completing nature, applying effort at the place before the body’s birth.

This is the practice of the lower virtue, its use unceasing, the path from striving to spontaneity. When spontaneity is attained, it is the same as the upper virtue. The above speaks of life principles; below speaks of nature principles—practitioners, take heed.

Internally to nurture the self, tranquil and empty-none. The original root hidden yet luminous, inwardly illuminating the body. Seal the senses, fortify the numinous root. The Three Lights submerged, warmly nurturing the child-pearl, invisible to sight yet near and easily sought. Diligently practice it, day and night without rest. After three years of refining and ingesting, one lightly ascends and travels afar, unscathed by fire, undampened by water. Able to preserve or abandon, ever joyful and without care. With the Dao accomplished and virtue perfected, one conceals and awaits the time. The Great One then summons, relocating to the Central Land. With merit complete, one ascends, receiving the register and chart.

The Dao of cultivating truth requires dual cultivation of nature and life, with practice in two stages. The external medicine completes life, the internal medicine completes nature. The external medicine externally seizes creation to restore the prenatal; the internal medicine internally preserves the original true to transform the postnatal. The prenatal is for shedding the illusory body, the postnatal for shedding the dharma-body.

Worldly deluded people, unaware of the sages’ profound intent in their teachings, mistakenly take the external medicine as furnace fire and the internal medicine as solitary cultivation. They do not know that the prenatal true yang comes from the empty-none, belonging to the other—hence called external medicine. Once the prenatal arrives, returning to the root and restoring life, it belongs to the self—hence called internal medicine. The division of internal and external marks the boundary of nature and life. Both emerge from the same source yet differ in name, both called the primordial of the primordial.

The opening of this section speaks of internally nurturing the self, making the principles of internal and external abundantly clear. It precisely aligns with the beginning’s aim to nurture nature and extend life. The self is nature. When the golden elixir is accomplished and the foundation of life is secured, one must urgently cultivate nature to shed the dharma-body.

chunks.original_text: 修性之道，乃炼神还虚之一着。 故此节直指曰：“内以养己，安静虚无。 ”盖养性之道，须要安身于虚，静心于无，身心两忘，期必至于形神俱妙，与道合真而后已。 原本隐明，内照形躯者，韬明养晦，允执厥中也。 闭塞其兑，筑固灵株者，惜气养神，惟精惟一也。 三光陆沉，温养子株者，精气神三宝精华，皆收敛于内，护持丹元，须臾不离也。 原本灵株子珠，皆圣胎之别名。 圣胎有气无质，故曰视之不见。 虽视不见，近在我身，切在心胸，人所不知，而己独知，须宜绵绵若存，勿忘勿助，日乾夕惕，勤而行之，夙夜不休。 十月丹熟，群阴剥尽时至脱化，身外有身。 更加三年乳哺之功，伏其气以壮神，食其时以固形，则来去自如，轻举远游，跨火不焦，入水不濡，聚则成形而存，散则化气而亡。 无灾无难，长乐无忧，到此地位，道成德就。 太乙乃召，移居中洲，洞天福地，与群真共受天禄。 更来尘世，积功累行，三千功满，八百行完，玉帝敕诏，紫府受职，大丈夫之能事毕矣。 《参同契》经文直指下篇 下篇配以伏食 惟昔圣贤，怀玄抱真，伏炼九鼎，化迹隐沦，含精养神，通德三光，津液腠理，筋骨致坚，众邪辟除，正气长存，积累长久，变形而仙。 忧悯后生，好道之伦，随傍风采，指画古文，着为图籍，开示后昆，露见枝条，隐藏本根，托号诸名，覆谬众文，学者得之，韫椟终身。 子继父业，孙踵祖先，传世迷惑，竟无见闻，遂使宦者不仕，农夫失耘，商人弃货，志士家贫。 吾甚伤之，定录此文，字约易思，事省不繁，披列其条，核实可观，分两有数，因而相循，故为乱辞，孔窍其门，智者审思，用意参焉。 性命之道，得其真者，勤而行之，立竿见影。 古来成道者，代不乏人。
chunks.translated_text:
The Way of cultivating nature is the crucial step of refining spirit and returning to emptiness. Thus, this section directly points: *"Nurture the self internally, resting in stillness and emptiness."* For the Way of nurturing nature requires settling the body in emptiness and calming the mind in nothingness, forgetting both body and mind, until form and spirit attain perfection and merge with the true Dao.

The original root, hidden yet luminous, inwardly illumines the body—this is concealing brilliance and nurturing obscurity, holding fast to the center. Closing the senses and fortifying the spiritual root—this is cherishing qi and nourishing spirit, preserving essence and maintaining oneness. The three luminaries submerged in darkness, warming and nurturing the child and sprout—this is the three treasures of essence, qi, and spirit, all gathered within, guarding the elixir’s origin without a moment’s separation.

The original root, spiritual sprout, and child-pearl are all alternate names for the sacred embryo. The sacred embryo has qi but no form, thus *"seen yet unseen."* Though unseen, it lies near within the body, close to the heart and breast—unknown to others but known only to oneself. One must maintain it with unbroken continuity, neither forgetting nor forcing, vigilant day and night, diligently practicing without rest. After ten months, the elixir ripens, all yin is stripped away, and when the time comes, transformation occurs—another body appears beyond the body.

With three more years of nursing, subduing qi to strengthen spirit and consuming seasonal essences to solidify form, one moves freely at will, ascending lightly on distant journeys, treading fire without burning, entering water without wetting. Gathered, one takes form and exists; scattered, one dissolves into qi and vanishes. Free from calamity and hardship, ever joyful and without sorrow—at this stage, the Dao is accomplished and virtue perfected. The Great One summons, relocating to the Central Continent, the grotto heavens and blessed lands, where one shares celestial blessings with the host of immortals.

Returning to the mundane world, one accumulates merit and piles up deeds. When three thousand merits are complete and eight hundred deeds fulfilled, the Jade Emperor issues a decree, and one receives office in the Purple Palace. Thus, the great man’s work is done.

The *Cantong Qi*’s scripture directly points to the lower chapter, which corresponds to the practice of ingesting and refining. Only the sages and worthies of old embraced mystery and held fast to truth, refining the nine cauldrons, concealing their traces and vanishing from the world. They contained essence and nurtured spirit, penetrating virtue through the three luminaries, enriching fluids and pores, strengthening sinews and bones. All evil was repelled, and upright qi endured. Through long accumulation, they transformed their forms and became immortals.

Pitying later generations who love the Dao, they followed the winds and emulated the ancients, illustrating ancient texts, composing diagrams and records to enlighten posterity. Yet they revealed only branches and leaves, hiding the root, adopting various names, and obscuring the true teachings. Scholars who obtained these works treasured them in caskets for life. Sons inherited their fathers’ work, grandsons followed their ancestors’ paths—transmitting through generations in confusion, never perceiving the truth. Thus, officials abandoned office, farmers neglected plowing, merchants forsook goods, and aspirants fell into poverty.

Deeply grieved, I have compiled this text, concise in words and easy to ponder, simple in matters and unburdened. Its clauses are laid out clearly, verifiable and observable. Weights and measures are precise, following one another in sequence. Thus, I have composed these disordered verses, opening the gates and apertures. The wise will reflect carefully and contemplate their meaning.

The Way of nature and life, when grasped in truth, yields immediate results when practiced diligently. Since ancient times, those who have attained the Dao have never been lacking.

The opening of this section speaks of internally nurturing the self, making the principles of internal and external abundantly clear. When the golden elixir is accomplished and the foundation of life is secured, one must urgently cultivate nature to shed the dharma-body.

chunks.original_text: 仙传云：“拔宅者八百，飞升者三千； 坐脱立亡，小成者不可枚举。 ”拔宅者，如黄帝焉，如许族阳焉，如张天师焉。 飞升者，如正阳翁焉，如葛仙翁焉，如河上公焉，如纯阳翁焉。 以上圣贤，皆炼七返九还，金液大丹而成。 若舍此道，冀望成真，万无是理。 金丹之道，怀玄抱真，伏炼九鼎之道也。 玄者，神妙不测，变化无端，气之谓。 真者，至善无恶，浑然元仁，理之谓。 气属命，理属性。 怀玄者，所以立命也。 抱真者，所以尽性也。 伏者，伏其气，所以养浩然正气，命由自造也。 炼者，炼其真，所以全本来天真，性不有昧也。 九者，纯阳无阴之数。 自古圣贤皆怀玄抱真，伏之炼之，归于纯阳无阴，为金刚不坏之物，是谓伏炼九鼎。 非后世九鼎炉火服食，亦非御女闺丹九鼎之邪说。 若是炉火闺丹，何言怀玄抱真？ 昔黄帝，太湖炼九鼎，乘龙上天公案。 太湖为坎龙，为乾阳，乃是取坎中之阳，以填离中之阴，复还乾体，归于纯阳之谓，何得以九鼎为有象之九鼎乎？ 惟此伏炼九鼎之道，大智若愚，大巧若拙，隐沦其远，韬明养晦，含藏精神。 默运神功，以窃造化之权，以盗阴阳之气。 《易》日：“与天地合其德，与月日合其明，与四时合其序，与鬼神合其吉凶。 ”惟其能合，所以通德三光，天关在手，地轴由心，以之保精则精粹，而津液腠理； 以之养气则气足，而筋骨致坚。 众邪辟除者，退阴也。 正气常存者，进阳也。 进阳退阴，加功伏炼，久而阴尽阳纯，形(疑为“精”之误)化为气，气化为神，神化为虚，身外有身，羽化登仙。 成己之后复成物，垂悯后生，好道之伦，趋入旁门，不知真道，于是指画古文，着作图籍，开万世之聋聩，作百代之阶梯，然其义深奥，谨露枝条。 至于本根，恐泄天机，不敢直吐，故隐藏耳。 隐藏者，非不言也，乃隐于言语之外，寓意之中耳。 后人不知古人妙旨，托诸真名号，妄作妄注，错谬古文，以误后学。 如阴符天真皇人讲语南华门，御寇玉清金笥录，皆后人指古人名号，妄续妄着者。 后之学人，不识真假，一遇此等谬文，韫椟终身，如获至宝。 父传于子，子传于孙，以迷传迷，以盲引盲，遂至宦者不仕，农夫失耘，商人志士，各废其业，终无一成。 仙翁慈悲，作《参同契》，字约而思之易入，事省而行之不繁，列其条而核其实。 其中火候分数，药物斤两，无不详明且备，可谓拨天根而钻理窟，真足为天下万人眼目性命孔窍，有志者见之，宜审思细参，久而自见端倪。 奈何后世，或指为纳甲之书，或猜为炉火之事，或取为御女之证。 此孔子不得不哭麟，卞和不得不泣玉，虽仙翁亦无如何也。 河上姹女，灵而最神，得火则飞，不见埃尘，鬼隐龙匿，莫知所存。 将欲制之，黄芽为根。 物无阴阳，违天背元，牝鸡自卵，其雏不全。 夫何故乎？ 配合未连，三五不交，刚柔离分。 施化之精，天地自然，火动炎上，水流润下，非有师导，使其然也。 资使统正，不可复改。 观夫雌雄，交媾之时，刚柔相结，而不可解，得其节符，非有工巧，以制御之。 男生而伏，女偃其躯，秉乎胞胎，受炁元初，非徒生时，着而见之。 及其死也，亦复效之，此非父母，教令使然。
chunks.translated_text:
The immortals’ traditions state: “Those who ascended with their households number eight hundred; those who soared aloft in flight number three thousand; those who departed seated or standing—minor attainments—cannot be counted.” Those who ascended with their households include the Yellow Emperor, the Xu family of Yang, and Master Zhang the Celestial Master. Those who soared aloft include the Venerable Zhengyang, the Venerable Ge the Immortal, the Elder of the Riverside, and the Venerable Pure Yang. All these sages and worthies refined the Seven Returns and Nine Revolutions, achieving the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid. To abandon this Way and hope for transcendence is utterly impossible.

The Way of the Golden Elixir is to embrace the mysterious and hold fast to the true, to subdue and refine the Way of the Nine Cauldrons. The mysterious is that which is wondrous and unfathomable, endlessly transforming—this is called *qi*. The true is perfect goodness without evil, utterly imbued with primordial benevolence—this is called *principle*. *Qi* pertains to *life-destiny*; *principle* pertains to *nature*. To embrace the mysterious is to establish *life-destiny*; to hold fast to the true is to fulfill *nature*. To subdue is to subdue one’s *qi*, thereby nurturing the vast and upright *qi*, for *life-destiny* is self-fashioned. To refine is to refine one’s true nature, thereby preserving the original celestial purity, lest *nature* be obscured. The number nine represents pure yang without yin.

Since ancient times, all sages and worthies embraced the mysterious and held fast to the true, subduing and refining until they returned to pure yang without yin, becoming indestructible as adamantine—this is called subduing and refining the Nine Cauldrons. It is not the later Nine Cauldrons of furnace fires for ingesting minerals, nor the perverse teachings of the Nine Cauldrons of bedchamber arts. If it were furnace fires or bedchamber arts, how could one speak of embracing the mysterious and holding fast to the true?

In former times, the Yellow Emperor refined the Nine Cauldrons at Lake Tai, then rode a dragon to ascend to heaven—a well-known case. Lake Tai represents the *kan* dragon and *qian* yang, for it is a matter of extracting the yang within *kan* to fill the yin within *li*, restoring the *qian* body and returning to pure yang. How could the Nine Cauldrons refer to tangible cauldrons?

Only this Way of subduing and refining the Nine Cauldrons appears foolish to the greatly wise and clumsy to the greatly skillful. It withdraws into obscurity, concealing brilliance and nurturing obscurity, harboring essence and spirit. Silently, it wields the power of the divine, usurping the authority of creation and stealing the *qi* of yin and yang. As the *Book of Changes* says: “Its virtue is one with heaven and earth; its brightness is one with the sun and moon; its sequence is one with the four seasons; its auspices and omens are one with ghosts and spirits.” Only by achieving such unity can one penetrate the virtue of the Three Luminaries, hold the Celestial Pass in hand, and turn the Earthly Axis by will. By preserving essence, essence becomes pure, and fluids permeate the interstices; by nurturing *qi*, *qi* becomes abundant, and sinews and bones grow firm.

Expelling all perverse influences is the retreat of yin; the constant presence of upright *qi* is the advance of yang. Advancing yang and retreating yin, with added effort in subduing and refining, over time yin is exhausted and yang is made pure. Form (likely “essence”) transforms into *qi*, *qi* transforms into spirit, spirit transforms into emptiness. Beyond the body, another body arises, and one ascends as a feathered immortal. After perfecting oneself, one perfects others, pitying later generations. Those who love the Way rush into side doors, unaware of the true Way. Thus, the ancients sketched ancient texts, composed illustrated works, opening the deaf ears of myriad ages and serving as stepping stones for a hundred generations. Yet their meaning is profound and abstruse, revealing only branches and leaves. As for the root, they feared leaking celestial secrets and dared not speak plainly—thus they concealed it.

Concealment does not mean silence; rather, it is hidden beyond words, embedded within their meaning. Later generations, unaware of the ancients’ sublime intent, falsely attributed works to real names, recklessly composing and annotating, distorting ancient texts and misleading later learners. Examples include *The Yellow Emperor’s Talks on the True*, *The Gate of Southern Flowers*, *The Jade Purity and Golden Casket Record*—all later fabrications falsely ascribed to ancient figures.

Later students, unable to discern truth from falsehood, upon encountering such spurious texts, treasure them as if they were supreme treasures. Fathers transmit them to sons, sons to grandsons, passing delusion to delusion, the blind leading the blind. Thus, officials abandon office, farmers neglect plowing, merchants and aspirants forsake their livelihoods, yet none achieve anything.

The immortal sages, moved by compassion, composed the *Cantong Qi*. Its words are concise and easy to ponder; its matters are simple and unburdened. Its clauses are laid out clearly, verifiable and observable. Within it, the timing of firing and the weights of medicinal substances are all detailed and complete. It may be called a work that pierces the heavenly root and bores into the cave of principle, truly serving as the eyes and apertures of life and destiny for the world’s myriad people. Those with aspiration who encounter it should reflect carefully and contemplate deeply; over time, the beginnings will naturally become clear.

Yet later generations have misconstrued it as a book of *na jia*, or guessed it to be about furnace fires, or taken it as proof of bedchamber arts. This is why Confucius could not but weep for the unicorn, and Bian He could not but weep for the jade—even the immortal sages could do nothing about it.

The maiden of the Yellow River is numinous and most divine. When fire is applied, she takes flight, unseen even by specks of dust. Ghosts hide and dragons conceal themselves—none know where she resides. To control her, the Yellow Sprout is the root.

Things without yin and yang violate heaven and oppose the primordial. A hen that lays eggs on its own will not hatch a complete chick. Why is this? Because the union is incomplete: the Three and Five do not merge, hardness and softness remain apart. The essence of transformation is natural to heaven and earth. Fire moves upward in its heat; water flows downward in its moisture—not because some master instructed them to do so. Their inherent nature and proper governance cannot be altered.

Observe the mating of male and female: when hardness and softness unite, they cannot be separated. Achieving their proper rhythm requires no craft or control. The male crouches while the female lies prone, receiving the *qi* of the primordial within the womb—not merely visible at birth. Even in death, they replicate this pattern—not because parents taught them to do so.

chunks.original_text: 本在交媾，定置始先。 上节言古来圣贤，皆怀玄抱真，而得成道。 夫怀玄抱真，刚柔相当，阴阳混合之道也。 姹女者，离中之阴，在人为人心之灵知。 人心具有识神，识神流性不定，借灵生妄， 如河上淫奔之女，故象河上姹女。 因其姹女其性流荡，见景生情，故灵。 惟其灵，逐风扬波，故神。 是谓昭昭灵灵之识神。 此神喜动不喜静，心火稍起，则飞扬腾空，如鬼隐龙匿，无影无踪，莫知所存矣。 将欲制之，黄芽为根者，黄芽为坎中之阳，在人即道心之真知。 真知具有真情，真情内含真意，乃是一点生机，别名曰黄芽。 真意属土，真土一现，阳气生机即回，如黄芽在地中，从根而渐长也。 灵知之流性属阴，真知之真意属阳，以真意制流性，拄杖稳定，识神不得而起，人心不得而发，灵知亦归于真知。 不但灵知不飞，而且能养真知。 真知灵知，两而合一，阴阳相应，生机不息矣。 《易》曰：“一阴一阳之谓道。 ”若物无阴无阳，违天背元，牝鸡自卵，其雏不全。 特以配合不连，五行不交，刚柔分离，非天地一阴一阳，施化自然之道，皆不能生育。 阳施阴化，其精流通，方是自然之道，方能万物生育。 比如火性炎上，水流润下，非有师导，资于本始； 雌雄交姤，刚柔相结，非有工巧出于同类。 又如男生而伏，女偃其躯，非徒生时着见，即死亦然。 非有父母教令，本在交姤，定置始先。 凡此皆阴阳二气感应，有莫之为而为，莫之致而至者也。 修道者，若舍阴阳之道，则孤阴不生，独阳不长，违天背元，生机已息，焉能保命？ 焉能全形？ 故必真知灵知，阴阳相合，方能济事也。 太阳流珠，常欲去人。 卒得金华，转而相因，化为白液，凝而至坚。 金华先唱，有倾之间，解化为水，马齿瓓玕，阳乃往和，情性自然。 迫促时阴，拘蓄禁门，慈母养育，孝子报恩，严父施令，教敕子孙。 五行错王，相据以生，火性销金，金伐木荣。 三五与一，天地至精，可以口诀，难以书传。 子当右转，午乃东旋，卯酉界隔，主客二名。 龙呼于虎，虎吸龙精，两相饮食，具相贪便，遂相衔咽，咀嚼相吞。 荧惑守西，太白经天，杀气所临，何有不倾。 狸犬守鼠，鸟雀畏鹯，各有其功，何敢有声。 不得其理，难以妄言。 竭殚家产，妻子饥贫，自古及今，好者亿人，记讫不谐遇，希有能成。 广求名药，与道乖殊。 上节言姹女得黄芽，方能制伏。 此节申明制伏之火候。 夫人所具灵知之流性，出入无时，莫知其乡，乱人之心思，耗人之精神，伤人之性命。 如太阳流珠，无时停息。 然虽无时停息，若得道心真知之金华以配之，则灵知得真知制伏，转而相因，灵归于真，以性求情，以情归性，化为白液，一气混合，凝而至坚矣。 真知灵知既凝，阴阳相合，和气熏蒸，真知之金华，顷刻之间，刚变为柔，解化为真一之水。 恍惚有物，杳冥有精，如马齿琅玗焉。 马齿比其坚白，琅玗比其温柔。 金华化水，即上所云，化为白液也。 马齿琅玗，即上所云，凝而至坚也。 真知金华，既变为真一之水，白嫩而坚。 灵知太阳流珠，即化为虚灵之火，而往和之。 金华先唱者，真情不昧也。 阳乃后和者，真性不迷也。 情不昧、性不迷，火不炎上，水不下流，水火相济，性情和平，归于不识不知，顺帝之则自然之域矣。
chunks.translated_text:
At its root lies the union of mating, where the initial placement is determined. The preceding section speaks of how ancient sages and worthies all embraced the mysterious and held fast to the true, thereby attaining the Dao. To embrace the mysterious and hold fast to the true is the Way of balanced hardness and softness, the merging of yin and yang.

The *chana* maiden is the yin within *li*, in humans corresponding to the numinous awareness of the human heart. The human heart possesses the *shen* of consciousness, and this *shen* of consciousness, with its unsteady nature, borrows from the numinous to generate delusion—like the wanton woman by the river, hence the image of the *chana* maiden by the river. Because her nature is unsteady, she reacts to every scene with emotion, thus she is numinous. Precisely because she is numinous, she chases the wind and stirs the waves, thus she is spirit. This is what is called the luminous, ever-aware *shen* of consciousness. This *shen* delights in movement and dislikes stillness; when the fire of the heart stirs even slightly, it soars and ascends into emptiness, like a ghost hiding or a dragon concealing itself, leaving no shadow or trace, its whereabouts unknown.

To restrain it, the *huangya* serves as the root. The *huangya* is the yang within *kan*, in humans corresponding to the true awareness of the Dao-heart. True awareness possesses true emotion, and true emotion inwardly contains true intent—this is a single spark of life, also named the *huangya*. True intent pertains to earth; when true earth appears, the yang *qi* of life immediately returns, like the *huangya* in the earth, growing gradually from the root. The unsteady nature of numinous awareness pertains to yin, while the true intent of true awareness pertains to yang. Using true intent to restrain the unsteady nature is like planting a staff firmly in the ground: the *shen* of consciousness cannot arise, the human heart cannot stir, and numinous awareness returns to true awareness. Not only does numinous awareness cease to fly, but it also nourishes true awareness. When true awareness and numinous awareness merge into one, yin and yang respond to each other, and the spark of life never ceases.

The *Yijing* states: “The interplay of one yin and one yang is called the Dao.” If a thing lacks yin or yang, it defies heaven and turns its back on the primordial. A hen that lays eggs on its own will not hatch a complete chick. Why is this? Because the union is incomplete: the Three and Five do not merge, hardness and softness remain apart. This is not the natural Way of heaven and earth, where one yin and one yang enact transformation. Only when yang bestows and yin transforms, with their essence flowing freely, does it accord with the natural Dao, enabling the birth and nurturing of the myriad things.

For example, the nature of fire is to blaze upward, and water flows downward in its moisture—not because some master instructed them to do so, but because they rely on their original nature. When male and female mate, hardness and softness unite—not through any craft or skill, but arising from their kind. Again, like the male crouching and the female lying prone, this is not merely visible at birth but persists even in death. Not because parents taught them, but because the union of mating determines the initial placement from the outset. All these are the mutual resonance of yin and yang *qi*, where things happen without deliberate action, arrive without being summoned.

For those who cultivate the Dao, if they abandon the Way of yin and yang, solitary yin cannot generate, and solitary yang cannot grow. Defying heaven and turning one’s back on the primordial, the spark of life is extinguished—how then can one preserve life? How can one preserve the body? Thus, only when true awareness and numinous awareness merge, when yin and yang unite, can the endeavor succeed.

The radiant pearl of the great yang constantly seeks to leave the person. Suddenly obtaining the golden flower, it turns and interacts, transforming into a white liquid that congeals into utmost firmness. The golden flower sings first, and in an instant, it dissolves and transforms into water—like horse’s teeth and *langgan* jade. Yang then goes to harmonize, and their natures and emotions become natural. Pressed by the timely yin, confined within the gate of restraint, the compassionate mother nurtures, the filial son repays kindness, the stern father issues commands, teaching and admonishing descendants. The five phases contend for supremacy, each relying on the other to generate. The nature of fire melts metal, and metal subdues the flourishing of wood. The Three and Five with the One are the utmost essence of heaven and earth. This can be transmitted orally but is difficult to convey in writing.

You should turn to the right, while *wu* rotates to the east. *Mao* and *you* form the boundary, with host and guest as the two names. The dragon calls to the tiger, and the tiger inhales the dragon’s essence. The two consume each other, each coveting the other’s advantage, then interlock and swallow, chewing and devouring one another. When *Yinghuo* guards the west and *Taibai* traverses the heavens, the *qi* of killing arrives—what could remain standing? The wildcat guards the mouse, and the sparrow fears the hawk—each has its function, so who dares make a sound? Without grasping the principle, one should not speak recklessly.

Those who exhaust their family wealth, leaving their wives and children hungry and impoverished, have existed by the millions from ancient times to the present. Few have succeeded, and rare are those who have achieved completion. Seeking famous medicines far and wide only strays from the Dao. The preceding section spoke of how the *chana* maiden, when she obtains the *huangya*, can be subdued. This section elaborates on the firing times required for subduing.

The unsteady nature of the numinous awareness inherent in humans comes and goes without cease, its whereabouts unknown. It disturbs the thoughts of the heart, depletes the spirit, and harms the nature and life—like the radiant pearl of the great yang, ceaseless in its movement. Yet though it never ceases, if it obtains the golden flower of the Dao-heart’s true awareness to pair with it, then numinous awareness is subdued by true awareness. Turning and interacting, the numinous returns to the true, seeking emotion through nature and returning emotion to nature. It transforms into a white liquid, a single *qi* merging and congealing into utmost firmness.

Once true awareness and numinous awareness congeal, yin and yang unite, and harmonious *qi* steams and rises. The golden flower of true awareness, in an instant, hardens and softens, dissolving into the water of true unity. In the indistinct, there is something; in the profound darkness, there is essence—like horse’s teeth in their firm whiteness and *langgan* jade in its gentle warmth. The golden flower transforming into water is what was previously called transforming into a white liquid. Horse’s teeth and *langgan* jade are what was previously called congealing into utmost firmness.

Once the golden flower of true awareness transforms into the water of true unity, it becomes white, tender, and firm. The radiant pearl of the great yang, the numinous awareness, then transforms into the ethereal fire of emptiness and goes to harmonize with it. The golden flower sings first—true emotion is not obscured. Yang then harmonizes afterward—true nature is not deluded. With emotion unobscured and nature undeluded, fire does not blaze upward, and water does not flow downward. Water and fire aid each other, nature and emotion become peaceful, returning to the realm of not knowing, not perceiving, and following the natural principle of the Lord on High.

chunks.original_text: 性情自然，方是凝而至坚，犹有一身后天阴气未化，足为道累。 必须将一身阴气化尽，方能大道完成。 迫促时阴者，却除邪气，时刻谨慎也。 拘蓄禁门者，护持正气，须臾不离也。 禁门即元牝之门，为生门死户，乃生杀之舍，阴阳之窍，生我在此，死我在此，结胎在此，脱胎亦在此。 守之考存，失之者亡，为至紧至要之关口，所以号为禁门。 此个门人人出入，个个来往，但百姓日用而不知耳。 若有人问此门形象，吾则曰天之下，地之上，日之西，月之东； 十字路头，四会场中，明晃晃开一孔窍，远观细如毫毛，近看大似世界。 其中万象森罗，百宝俱备，有天造地设家当，不知有人认得否？ 若有人认得，则迫促邪阴，于死我处返其本，拘蓄正阳，于生我处还其元，可以随心运用，左之右之，无不宜之矣。 但还元返本之道，总是调和性情，混合阴阳之理。 若要调和性情，须先辩明五行生克之道。 金生水，金为水母，水为金子； 木生火，木为火父，火为木子。 金本生水，水中又能生金，是谓慈母养育，孝子报恩也。 木本生火。 火生又能成木，是谓严父施令，教敕子孙也。 金生水，木生火，顺生也； 水生金，火生木，逆生也。 又有五行错王，相据以生之道，如火性能以销金，金被火克而色足，能以生旺； 金性能以伐木，木被金克而成器，得以生荣之类。 三五者，金生水一五； 木生火一五； 土居中央自为一五。 一者，一气也。 五行相生相克，克以成生，生以全克，生克随时，一气流行，始而终，终而始，神化不测。 在天地则为至精，在丹道则为至宝。 此中顺逆生克之天机，可以口诀，难以书传也。 难以书传者，以其顺逆生克之天机，有火候、有工程、有先后、有急缓，差之毫发，失之千里。 书何尝不传火候？ 何尝不传工程？ 但言之而言不及，论之而论不尽耳。 仙翁老婆心多，既云难以书传，而又不得不以书传者，特欲以书传之，使后世学者，就文穷理，求师印证也。 书传者何事？ 即传火候工程耳。 子为六阳之首，乃一阳来复之时，逢子自左而右转，以至于巳，六阳全。 此进阳火之事，行刚道也。 午为六阴之首，乃一阴来姤之时，遇午自西而东旋，以至于亥，六阴纯。 此运阴符之事，用柔道也。 卯酉者，阴阳出入之门户。 卯为木，在东，为主，司生气； 酉为金，在西，为客，司杀气。 木性柔，象龙。 金性刚，象虎。 有杀有生，有主有客，生杀并用，主客相当，性情一气，如龙呼于虎，虎吸龙精，两相饮食，俱相贪恋，衔咽咀嚼，自然结丹。 比如荧惑为火星，宜在于南，若守于西，是火去克金。 太白为金星，宜在夜行，若经天昼现，是阴侵其阳。 二者皆反其常，系杀气所临，必有倾败大事之凶。 又如狸犬守鼠，必得鼠； 鹞拘鸟雀，必得功。 即此数事以观，阴阳失时必倾败，阴阳有准必成功。 以上皆书之所传者。 修道者，仅玩其所取之象，不得其所藏之理，妄猜私议，误认为褰鸢耸饔诼穑涨α豆唛榧也拮蛹⒑Ｗ怨偶敖瘢奘耍愿捍厦鳎磺竺魇诰鳎闱竺约傥妫笥叮氲拦造澹瘴抟怀桑刹惶局睿/font> 丹砂木精，得金乃并，金水合处，木火为侣。
chunks.translated_text:
When nature and emotion are in their natural state, this is what is meant by "congealing into utmost firmness." Yet there remains postnatal yin qi throughout the body that has not been transformed, which becomes a burden to the Dao. Only when all the yin qi in the body is fully transmuted can the great Dao be completed.

To press and hasten the yin is to expel perverse qi—this must be done with constant vigilance. To restrain and store at the Gate of Prohibition is to safeguard the upright qi—this must never be neglected for even a moment. The Gate of Prohibition is the Gate of the Mysterious Female, the portal of life and death, the abode of generation and destruction, the aperture of yin and yang. Here I am born, here I die; here the embryo is formed, and here it is delivered. Guard it and you preserve life; lose it and you perish. It is the most critical and essential threshold, hence called the Gate of Prohibition. This gate is where every person enters and exits, where each comes and goes, yet the common folk use it daily without awareness.

If someone asks about the form of this gate, I would say: beneath heaven, above earth, west of the sun, east of the moon; at the crossroads, in the center where the four directions meet, a luminous aperture opens—distant, it appears as fine as a hair; near, it seems as vast as a world. Within it, the ten thousand images stand in array, and the hundred treasures are all present. It is a celestial and terrestrial endowment, yet who among men recognizes it?

If someone recognizes it, then by pressing and hastening the perverse yin, one returns to the root at the place of death; by restraining and storing the upright yang, one restores the origin at the place of life. Thus one can wield it at will, directing it left or right, with nothing amiss.

Yet the Way of returning to the origin and restoring the root is fundamentally the principle of harmonizing nature and emotion, and blending yin and yang. To harmonize nature and emotion, one must first discern the Way of the five phases’ generation and restriction.

Metal generates water: metal is the mother of water, water the child of metal. Wood generates fire: wood is the father of fire, fire the child of wood. Metal inherently generates water, yet within water, metal can again be generated—this is the loving mother nurturing, the filial child repaying kindness. Wood inherently generates fire, yet fire can in turn complete wood—this is the stern father issuing commands, instructing and disciplining descendants.

Metal generating water and wood generating fire are the sequence of generation. Water generating metal and fire generating wood are the reversal of generation. There is also the Way of the five phases’ mutual overcoming and interdependent generation, as when the nature of fire can melt metal: though metal is restricted by fire, its luster is fulfilled, enabling it to flourish. Or when the nature of metal can fell wood: though wood is restricted by metal, it is shaped into implements and thus attains vitality.

The three fives: metal generating water is one five; wood generating fire is one five; earth, residing at the center, is itself one five. The one is the one qi. The five phases generate and restrict one another—restriction completes generation, generation fulfills restriction. Generation and restriction follow the seasons, the one qi flowing ceaselessly, beginning and ending, ending and beginning, its divine transformations unfathomable. In heaven and earth, it is the utmost essence; in the alchemical Way, it is the supreme treasure.

This celestial mechanism of sequential and reversed generation and restriction can be transmitted orally but is difficult to convey in writing. It is difficult to convey in writing because the celestial mechanism of sequential and reversed generation and restriction involves fire times, work phases, order, and urgency. A deviation by a hair’s breadth leads one astray by a thousand miles.

Why say writing does not transmit fire times? Why say it does not transmit work phases? It is not that they are not transmitted in writing, but that words fall short, and discourse cannot exhaust them. The immortal elders, with their boundless compassion, declare it difficult to transmit in writing yet cannot refrain from doing so, wishing thereby to guide later learners to delve into the text and seek a teacher’s verification.

What does writing transmit? It transmits fire times and work phases. The *zi* hour is the first of the six yang, the time when the one yang returns. When *zi* is encountered, turn from left to right until *si*, where the six yang are complete—this is the work of advancing the yang fire, following the path of hardness. The *wu* hour is the first of the six yin, the time when the one yin encounters. When *wu* is met, rotate from west to east until *hai*, where the six yin are pure—this is the work of circulating the yin tally, employing the path of softness.

*Mao* and *you* are the gates of yin and yang’s entry and exit. *Mao* is wood, in the east, the host, governing generative qi. *You* is metal, in the west, the guest, governing destructive qi. The nature of wood is soft, like the dragon. The nature of metal is hard, like the tiger. There is destruction and generation, host and guest; destruction and generation are employed together, host and guest are balanced. Nature and emotion are one qi—like the dragon exhaling toward the tiger, the tiger inhaling the dragon’s essence. The two devour each other, both covetous and enamored, swallowing and chewing, and the elixir naturally coalesces.

For example, Mars, the fire star, should be in the south; if it guards the west, fire goes to restrict metal. Venus, the metal star, should move at night; if it appears in the daytime sky, yin encroaches upon yang. Both are contrary to their norm, subject to destructive qi, and portend calamitous upheaval.

Again, like a cat guarding a mouse—it will surely catch the mouse; a hawk seizing a sparrow—it will surely succeed. From these examples, we see that when yin and yang miss their time, there is certain ruin; when yin and yang adhere to their measure, there is certain success. All the above are what writing transmits.

Yet cultivators of the Dao merely contemplate the images taken but fail to grasp the principles concealed within. They idly speculate and privately conjecture, mistaking the soaring kite for a hovering hawk, the leaping fish for a diving gull. They take the false for the true, the counterfeit for the genuine, and thus lose the great Way, wasting their years in vain. If one does not understand the root, one cannot fathom the branches; if one does not know the beginning, one cannot reach the end.

When cinnabar and wood essence obtain metal, they unite; where metal and water merge, wood and fire become companions.

chunks.original_text: 四者混沌，列为龙虎，龙阳数奇，虎阴数偶。 肝青为父，肺白为母，肾黑为子，心赤为女，脾黄为祖，子午行始。 三物一家，都归戊己。 上二节言姹女黄芽，流珠金华，凡以明调和阴阳之功耳。 夫调和阴阳之功，即是攒族五行之功。 故此节言攒族五行之事，申明调和阴阳之妙用也。 丹砂象火，在人为灵知之神，即是诧女流珠之别名也。 木性柔，在人为灵知之柔性； 金情刚，在人为真知之刚情，即前黄芽金华之一物也。 灵知之性，出于柔神，故为木之精。 因其性柔而少果断，人心识神借灵生妄，未免真中有假。 然得真知金刚制之，识神不得用事，人心安静，灵返本性，火中又生木。 本性爱金顺义，金情恋木慈仁，而金木相并。 灵知者，先天所秉之灵气； 真知者，先天所秉之正气。 此灵此真，本来合一，灵而有真，真而至灵，真空妙用，所谓一点真灵者是也。 因交后天，识神用事，灵者有昧，真者入假，彼此间隔，于是气性发而妄情起，一身纯阴矣。 识神者，历劫轮回之种子，生生死死之根蒂。 若不将此一物除灭，性命终非我有。 除灭之法，非真知之真情不能。 真知之情，具有先天真一之气。 此气至大至刚，能以退群魔、斩三尸。 真情一现，识神渐消； 识神消，而人心不起； 人心不起，灵知不飞； 灵知不飞，真性自现。 真性现而与真情相会，合而为一，是谓金木交并。 金木既交并，则金中有真水，在人为真精。 真精真情，合为一家，是谓金水合处。 木中含火，在人为元神。 元神真性，合为一家，是谓木火为侣。 外而金木相并，内而水火相济，四者混沌而为一气，仍是一阴一阳相合之理，故曰列为龙虎。 龙为木，属于阳，生数三，为奇； 虎为金，属于阴，生数四，为偶。 龙虎者，性情之法象。 性情精神虽分四象，而实一情一性统之。 虽是一情一性统之，其实到性情相合时，总是先天一气统之。 一气浑然，内含四象； 四象混合，仍是一气。 金丹之道，后天中返先天，攒簇五行，和合四象，凡以为调和阴阳耳。 阴阳调和，即是龙虎相会，故丹成曰龙虎大丹。 比如幻身，亦借阴阳五行而成。 肝青为木，为父； 肺白为金，为母； 肾黑为水，为子； 心赤为火，为女； 脾黄为土，为祖。 盖后天幻身，非五行不能成形； 先天真身，非五行不能凝结。 所异者，颠倒顺逆之间。 顺之则生人生物，逆之则成圣成仙。 何谓顺？ 肝木藏魂，性浮而主喜； 心火藏神，性炎而主乐； 肾水藏精，性流而主哀； 肺金藏魄，性沉而主怒； 脾土藏意，性滞而主欲； 属于后天。 何谓逆？ 木性浮而使沉，木归于根，喜化为仁； 金性沉而使浮，金还其元，怒化为义； 水性下而使上，水归于源，哀化为智； 火性上而使下，火返其真，乐化成礼； 土性滞而使和，土返于阳，欲化为信； 属于先天。 至人者，修其先天，化其后天。 逆运其机，以夺造化之权，以转生杀之柄。 其妙在乎抑阴扶阳，用六而不为六所用，用九而不为九所用也。 九者阳之数，六者阴之数。 一阳生为子，一阴生为午。 子午者，阴阳之始。 一阳生而进阳火，水木居焉； 一阴生而运阴符，火金居焉。 进阳运阴，各随其时，其中有信。 土居中央，混合百神，功归戊己。 戊以和阳，主运外；

chunks.original_text: 己以和阴，主养内。 戊己相合，内外如一。 二土结为刀圭，是谓三物一家，《金丹四百字》所谓“铅汞归真土，身心寂不动”者，即本此也。 盖金水属于身，木火属于心，戊己属于意，统精气神三物，炼精化气，炼气化神，炼神还虚，到此地位，身心如一，水无渗漏之患。 但所谓身心者，非幻身肉心，乃不可见之身心。 不可见之身，即本来一点浩然刚正之气； 不可见之心，即本来一点虚灵不昧之性。 所谓意者，非意念之意，即本来不动不摇之天，则谓之真意，人谓真信。 后人不知古人立言奥意，认身为幻化之身，认心为肉团之心，认意为意念之意。 执心者，入于寂灭之学； 认幻身者，认为搬运之功。 噫！ 以此为道，乃邪道耳，非正道也。
chunks.translated_text:
"Ji harmonizes yin and governs internal nurturance. When *wu* and *ji* unite, inner and outer become as one. The two earths congeal into the *daogui*; this is called 'three things as one family.' What the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* refers to as 'lead and mercury return to true earth, body and mind still and unmoving' originates here.

Now, metal and water belong to the body; wood and fire belong to the mind; *wu* and *ji* belong to intention. Together they govern the three things—essence, *qi*, and spirit—refining essence into *qi*, refining *qi* into spirit, refining spirit to return to emptiness. At this stage, body and mind become one, and water suffers no leakage.

Yet this so-called body and mind are not the illusory physical body and fleshly heart, but rather the invisible body and mind. The invisible body is the original, vast, upright, and unyielding *qi*; the invisible mind is the original, empty, numinous, and unobscured nature. The so-called intention is not the intention of thoughts, but rather the originally unmoving and unshaking heaven—this is called true intention, what people call true faith.

Later generations, unaware of the profound meaning in the ancients’ words, mistake the body for the illusory physical form, the mind for the fleshly heart, and intention for the intention of thoughts. Those who cling to the mind enter the study of extinction; those who recognize the illusory body regard it as the work of moving *qi*. Alas! To take this as the Dao is but a deviant path, not the true Way."

chunks.original_text: 彼安知道，乃先天之学，不落于有无形象，别有个心传口授之秘诀，直超彼岸，立跻圣位耶。 刚柔迭兴，更历分布。 龙西虎东，建纬卯酉，刑德并会，相见欢喜，刑主伏杀，德主生起。 二月榆落，魁临于卯，八月麦生，天罡据酉。 子南午北，互为纲纪。 一九之数，终而复始。 含元虚危，播精于子。 上节言攒簇五行，阴阳合一之功。 此节言阴阳合一之妙用。 金丹之道，刚柔相合之道。 刚中有柔，柔中有刚，刚柔互相迭兴，更历分布，随时变通耳。 何谓刚柔迭兴，更历分布？ 龙性属木，为德，本居于东卯阳位，而今反建纬于西酉阴位，是刚更历而布于柔地，此以性求情也。 虎情属金，为刑，本居于西酉阴位，而今反建纬于东卯阳位，是柔更历而布于刚地，此以情归性也。 以性求情，刑中有德； 以情归性，德中有刑。 刑中有德，德中有刑，刑德并会，性情相见，刚柔和合，如夫妻相得而欢喜矣。 试以天地造化之道论之，造为德，化为刑。 刑主杀，所以伏藏万物； 德主生，所以起于万物。 生以荣旺之，杀以收敛之。 有刑有德，有生有杀，生而杀，杀而生。 刑而德，德而刑，而造化得以流行不息矣。 然犹有生中有杀，杀中又有生之道，如二月万物皆生，榆荚反落，魁星辰时临卯，罡星辰时指酉，此生中有杀也。 八月万物皆收，荠麦反生，罡星戌时指酉，魁星戌时临卯，此杀中有生也。 盖罡星所指处吉，有生气也； 魁星所临处凶，有杀气也。 二月榆落，八月麦生，此皆刑德并会之象。 修道者，知得此刑德并会之机，方可下手。 子南午北，互为纲纪者，子属水，在人为元精； 午属火，在人为元神。 子在南，水居火位； 午在北，火居水位。 是精一之水，去克元神之火，刑也，杀也。 然水上火下，水火有相济之功，是以精养神，以神保精，刑中有德，德中有刑也。 刑中有德，德中有刑，刑德阴阳，互为纲纪，而生先天真阳。 阳生于一，而成于九，阳极而阴接，阳极而阳起，终而复始，阴阳并用，刑德两全，无伤于彼，有益于我。 彼我会则性情合，性情合则金丹结。 然其最要处，在一阳来复之时。 此时与天地合其德，与日月合其明，与四时合其序，与鬼神合其吉凶。 盖以此时有先天元精元气在焉。 虚危二星，位居子地，乃阴阳二气交会之处，即修道者安身立命之处，易错而难逢。 此时宜刑德并用，刑以防阴，德以养阳。 若有德无刑，客气乘间而入，先天有伤，大事去矣。 仙翁以“播精于子”一句示人以刑德并用，下手之诀，天机大露矣。 如审遭逢，观其端绪。 以类相况，揆物始终。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who mistakenly believe they know the Dao do not realize it is the study of the primordial, transcending all form and image—possessing instead a secret transmission of heart and mouth that directly crosses to the other shore and ascends to sagehood.

Hard and soft alternate in rise, traversing and distributing in turn. The Dragon lies west, the Tiger east; the weft is established at *mao* and *you*. Punishment and virtue converge, meeting in joy. Punishment governs restraint and slaying; virtue governs generation and ascent. In the second month, the elm scatters its samaras as *Kui* arrives at *mao*; in the eighth month, wheat sprouts as *Tian’gang* occupies *you*. *Zi* lies south, *wu* north, each serving as the other’s guiding principle. The numbers one and nine cycle endlessly, beginning anew.

The preceding section spoke of gathering the Five Agents and uniting yin and yang in practice; this section speaks of the wondrous function of their union. The Way of the Golden Elixir is the Way of hard and soft in harmony. Within hardness there is softness, within softness there is hardness—hard and soft alternate in rise, traversing and distributing, adapting to time and circumstance.

What is meant by "hard and soft alternate in rise, traversing and distributing"? The Dragon’s nature pertains to wood and virtue, originally dwelling in the yang position of *mao* in the east; yet now it establishes its weft in the yin position of *you* in the west—this is hardness traversing and distributing into the realm of softness, seeking emotion through nature. The Tiger’s emotion pertains to metal and punishment, originally dwelling in the yin position of *you* in the west; yet now it establishes its weft in the yang position of *mao* in the east—this is softness traversing and distributing into the realm of hardness, returning emotion to nature. Seeking emotion through nature, punishment contains virtue; returning emotion to nature, virtue contains punishment. Punishment contains virtue, virtue contains punishment—punishment and virtue converge, nature and emotion meet, hard and soft harmonize, like husband and wife rejoicing in union.

Consider the Dao of heaven and earth’s creation and transformation: creation is virtue, transformation is punishment. Punishment governs slaying, thereby concealing and storing the myriad things; virtue governs generation, thereby raising the myriad things. Generation flourishes and exalts them; slaying gathers and restrains them. There is punishment and virtue, generation and slaying—generation gives way to slaying, slaying gives way to generation. Punishment yields to virtue, virtue yields to punishment, and thus creation and transformation flow without cease.

Yet within generation there is slaying, and within slaying there is generation. In the second month, when all things are born, the elm’s samaras scatter instead; *Kui* arrives at *mao* in its hour, while *Gang* points to *you*—this is generation containing slaying. In the eighth month, when all things are gathered, shepherd’s purse and wheat sprout instead; *Gang* points to *you* in its hour, while *Kui* arrives at *mao*—this is slaying containing generation. For where *Gang* points is auspicious, possessing generative qi; where *Kui* arrives is inauspicious, possessing slaying qi. The elm’s scattering in the second month and wheat’s sprouting in the eighth month are both images of punishment and virtue converging. Only when cultivators understand this mechanism of punishment and virtue converging can they proceed.

*Zi* lies south and *wu* north, each serving as the other’s guiding principle: *zi* pertains to water, which in humans is primordial essence; *wu* pertains to fire, which in humans is primordial spirit. When *zi* is in the south, water occupies the position of fire; when *wu* is in the north, fire occupies the position of water. This is the water of unified essence seeking to overcome the fire of primordial spirit—punishment, slaying. Yet when water ascends and fire descends, water and fire assist one another; thus essence nourishes spirit, and spirit preserves essence—punishment contains virtue, virtue contains punishment. Punishment contains virtue, virtue contains punishment; punishment and virtue, yin and yang, serve as each other’s guiding principles, thereby generating primordial true yang. Yang arises from one and completes at nine; when yang reaches its extreme, yin follows, and when yang reaches its extreme, yang arises—cycling endlessly. Yin and yang are employed together, punishment and virtue are both fulfilled, harming neither self nor other. When self and other meet, nature and emotion unite; when nature and emotion unite, the Golden Elixir coalesces.

Yet the most crucial moment lies in the return of the first yang. At this time, one’s virtue aligns with heaven and earth, one’s brightness aligns with the sun and moon, one’s sequence aligns with the four seasons, and one’s fortune aligns with spirits and gods. For at this moment, primordial essence and primordial qi are present. The stars *Xu* and *Wei* reside in the position of *zi*, the place where yin and yang qi converge—this is where cultivators establish their destiny, a moment easy to miss and difficult to encounter. At this time, one must employ both punishment and virtue: punishment to guard against yin, virtue to nourish yang. If there is virtue without punishment, guest qi seizes the opportunity to enter, injuring the primordial and ruining the great endeavor.

The immortal elder’s phrase "disseminating essence at *zi*" reveals the secret of employing both punishment and virtue, the crucial technique for beginning—here the celestial mechanism is fully exposed. If one carefully encounters this moment, observing its signs and patterns, comparing like to like, and measuring the beginning and end of things, success may be attained.

chunks.original_text: 五行相克，更为父母。 母含滋液，父主秉与，凝精流形，金石不朽。 审专不泄，得为成道。 立竿见影，呼谷传响。 岂不灵哉！ 天地至象。 若以野葛一寸，巴豆一两，入喉辄僵，不得父俛仰。 当此之时，虽周文揲蓍，孔子占象，扁鹊操针，巫咸扣鼓，安能令苏，复起驰走？ 以上修炼金丹之道，内外药物，阴阳符火，精且详矣。 但恐学者，无大福分，不能遇真师耳。 如其遭逢，庆幸得遇真师，当究其大道之端绪，审其同类之药物，揆度下手之始，完全之终，而后可以修为。 盖一处不知，即一处有迷； 知之不精，即行之不到。

The Five Phases overcome one another, yet each becomes the parent of the next. The mother contains the nourishing fluids, the father governs bestowal and reception—essence congeals and form flows, enduring as metal and stone. With focused attention and no leakage, one may attain the Dao and achieve completion. Erect a pole and see its shadow; call into the valley and hear the echo—how could this not be wondrous? Such are the supreme images of Heaven and Earth.

Yet if one were to take a mere inch of wild aconite or a single ounce of croton seed, swallowing them would cause instant collapse, leaving one unable to rise or bow. At such a moment, even if King Wen were casting yarrow stalks, Confucius interpreting the hexagrams, Bian Que wielding his needles, or Wu Xian beating his drum, how could they revive the fallen or restore them to swift movement?

The above speaks of the Way of refining the Golden Elixir, detailing the inner and outer medicinal substances, the yin-yang talismans and firing times—both precise and thorough. Yet one fears that scholars may lack the great good fortune to encounter a true teacher. Should they be so fortunate as to meet one, they must investigate the origins of the great Way, examine the medicinal substances of their own kind, measure the beginning of the initial step, and complete the final stage of perfection. Only then may they proceed with cultivation.

For wherever there is ignorance, there lies confusion; where knowledge is imprecise, practice will fall short.

chunks.original_text: 所谓差之毫发，失之千里。 五行相克者，金克木，木克土，土克水，水克火，火克金也。 更为父母者，金生水，水生木，木生火，火生土，土生金，五行相生，彼此互为父母也。 五行之中，水木属阳，为父； 火金属阴，为母。 父主刚，母主柔。 母含滋液者，柔以成物也； 父主秉与者，刚以生物也。 一生一成，金水木火，二五之精，妙合而凝，品物流行矣。 修道者，能明五行生克之理，阴阳五运之理，宜刚即刚，，宜柔即柔，刚柔归于中正，圣胎凝结，无形生形，十月气足，露出法身，不生不灭，与金石不朽。 若有知而审专不泄，勤行不怠者，决得成道。 如立竿见影，呼谷传响，其灵验最为迅速。 要之，天地非阴阳不能生物，性命非阴阳不能结丹，天地造化之道，乃金丹之至象也。 后世迷人，不究真阴真阳之理，趋入旁径，到老无成，妄言修道为虚妄，圣贤之文为虚文，彼特未之深思耳。 试观后天野葛巴豆之毒，入口即便尸僵，虽圣贤仙佛，亦难救苏。 况金丹乃先天至宝，岂有得之而不能永寿长生者哉？ 金丹之能长生，犹之巴葛之能致死，人之不思，愚之甚矣。 紫阳欲向人间留秘诀，未逢一个是知音，正为此耳。 参同契笺注原序 《参同契》者，辞寡而道大，言微而旨深。 列五帝以建业，配三皇而立政。 若君臣差殊，上下无准，序以为政，不至太平。
