chunks.original_text: 上节言上德下德，有为无为二法。 此节细言下德有为之妙用。 下德者，有为之道，后天中返先天也。 后天中返先天，先要知真金一味大药。 此金非世间之凡金，乃吾固有真知之真金也。 此金经火锻炼，与天地并长久，与日月共光明。 故丹成之后，名曰金丹。 以其丹由金成，临炉下功，首以金为堤防。 堤防者，堤防金之生水也。 堤防金生水者，将以为入水计耳。 入水者，非入泛滥之水，乃入精一之水。 丹道用金之事大，入水之事亦不小。 防金在于不即不离之功，入水在于不急不缓之妙。 不即不离，杀中有生，不急不缓，柔中藏刚。 优游者，从容自然，以逸待劳，以静候动耳。 防金入水之妙，莫先知其金水之本数。 真知之真金，自一阳复，而渐至于纯全，圆陀陀，光灼灼。 通幽达明，如十五之月，光辉盈轮，无处不照，取数为十五两，此金之本数也。 有一分金，即生一分水。 有一两金，即生一两水。 如月十六，一阴潜生。 至三十日，光辉尽消，复为黑体，取数亦为十五两。 故曰金计有十五，水数亦如之。 用水之法，别有妙用，不得以本数用之。 比如水之本数固有十五两，生到五分，则为有余之水，已不可入矣，只生到二分，则为精一之真水，正宜入之。 水真则水能生金，是母隐于子胎，子报母恩也。 金不泄气，无伤于金，故金重如本初，不失其十五两之本数也。 若水生到三分，亦谓有余，遂不堪入。 学者须要知的水有清浊之分、壬癸之别。 壬水清，属阳； 癸水浊，属阴。 壬水有气而无质，为精一不二之真水； 癸水纯阴而有质，为泛滥交杂之污水。 二分水如泉中方出未流之水，至清至洁，壬水也。 三分水已流而染尘，五分水渐流至远，已混浊不堪，此皆癸水也。 丹道入水只取其气，不取其质。 用质伤其金，用气辅其金。 故以二分之水，辅助十五两之金也。 然入水得真，入火亦不可无候。 火者，虚灵之神。 阴阳之和气，水用二分，火亦须用二分。 二分之火，如初燃之火，温而不燥，明而无焰。 水用二分，不失其金之重； 火用二分，不克其金之体。 如是配合，则水来济火，而火不燥； 火来炼金，而金生明； 金来生水，而水有本。 水火相济，金火同宫，三物自相含受，变之化之，神妙不测矣。 盖三物含受，是三而归一。 鼎炉之中，药即是火，火即是药，药火相生，和气熏蒸。 内有太阳灵光，一点真火锻炼。 须臾之间，真金溶化成液，由嫩渐坚。 变白为黄，号曰黄舆。 黄者中色，舆者土象。 金具燥气，遇火而燥气顿消，刚化为柔，刚柔如一，阴阳混合，归于中正之地，名曰黄舆，又名金丹。 圣人修炼大丹，攒年至月，攒月至日，攒日至时。 以法追摄，于一时辰内，天地造化夺尽，阴阳五行夺尽，万物气数夺尽，易错难逢，倘差之毫发，失之千里，毁性伤寿，得而复失。 当此之时，须宜大用现前，外观其形，形无其形，内观其心，心无其心。 形体俱忘，无烟无火，如灰如土，如明窗尘。 捣治并合者，刚柔俱化，形迹全无也。 送入赤色门者，虚灵不昧，无微不照也。 固塞其际会，务令致完坚者，还丹在一时，温养须十月。 固济牢封，须臾不离，不到胎完神全之时，而温养之功不得休歇也。 炎火张于下，昼夜声正勤者。
chunks.translated_text:
The preceding section speaks of higher virtue and lower virtue, of the two methods of *youwei* (action) and *wuwei* (non-action). This section elaborates on the wondrous application of lower virtue through *youwei*. Lower virtue is the Dao of action, the return from the postnatal to the prenatal. To return from the postnatal to the prenatal, one must first know the true gold—a singular great medicine. This gold is not the common gold of the world, but the true gold inherent in our original knowing. Refined by fire, this gold endures as long as heaven and earth, shines as brightly as the sun and moon. Thus, after the elixir is formed, it is called the Golden Elixir. Since the elixir is wrought from gold, when tending the furnace and applying effort, gold is first used as the embankment.

The embankment serves to contain the water born of gold. Containing the water born of gold is but a strategy for entering water. Entering water does not mean entering overflowing water, but the water of essence and oneness. The use of gold in the Dao of the Elixir is of great importance, and the matter of entering water is no small affair. Containing gold lies in the work of neither clinging nor separating; entering water lies in the subtlety of neither haste nor delay. Neither clinging nor separating means life within destruction; neither haste nor delay means strength concealed within softness. To move with ease is to act with natural composure, to await labor with leisure, to await movement with stillness.

The subtlety of containing gold and entering water begins with knowing the fundamental measures of gold and water. The true gold of true knowing, from the return of the first yang, gradually attains perfection—round and luminous, penetrating the obscure and illuminating the bright, like the moon on the fifteenth night, its radiance filling the orb, shining everywhere. Its measure is taken as fifteen *liang*: this is the fundamental measure of gold. For every part of gold, one part of water is born; for every *liang* of gold, one *liang* of water is born. Like the moon on the sixteenth night, a single yin stealthily arises. By the thirtieth day, its radiance is entirely spent, returning to a dark body—its measure is also fifteen *liang*. Thus, it is said that gold measures fifteen, and water’s measure is the same.

The method of using water, however, has its own subtleties and cannot be applied according to its fundamental measure. Though water’s fundamental measure is indeed fifteen *liang*, if it grows to five parts, it becomes excess water and can no longer be used. Only when it reaches two parts is it the true water of essence and oneness, precisely fit for entry. When water is true, it can generate gold—this is the mother concealed within the child’s womb, the child repaying the mother’s kindness. If gold does not leak *qi*, it remains unharmed, retaining its original weight of fifteen *liang*. If water grows to three parts, it is also deemed excess and unfit for use.

The adept must discern that water has distinctions of clarity and turbidity, of *ren* and *gui*. *Ren*-water is clear and belongs to yang; *gui*-water is turbid and belongs to yin. *Ren*-water has *qi* but no substance, being the true water of essence and oneness; *gui*-water is purely yin and possesses substance, being the polluted water of overflow and mixture. Two parts of water are like the spring’s source, just emerged and unstained—utterly clear, this is *ren*-water. Three parts of water have flowed and gathered dust; five parts, having flowed far, are already turbid and unusable—these are all *gui*-water. In the Dao of the Elixir, only the *qi* of water is taken, not its substance. Using substance harms the gold; using *qi* assists it. Thus, two parts of water assist fifteen *liang* of gold.

Yet when entering water is true, entering fire must also be timed. Fire is the spirit of emptiness and numinosity, the harmonious *qi* of yin and yang. If water is used in two parts, fire must also be used in two parts. Two parts of fire are like a newly kindled flame—warm but not parching, bright but without blaze. Using two parts of water does not diminish the weight of gold; using two parts of fire does not harm the body of gold. When thus combined, water comes to aid fire, and fire does not scorch; fire comes to refine gold, and gold shines forth; gold comes to generate water, and water has its source. Water and fire assist each other, gold and fire share the same chamber, and the three substances naturally intermingle, transforming and transmuting in wondrous ways beyond measure.

For when the three substances intermingle, they become three returning to one. Within the crucible, the medicine is the fire, and the fire is the medicine—medicine and fire generate each other, their harmonious *qi* steaming and suffusing. Within, the radiant light of the great yang and a single point of true fire refine the gold. In an instant, the true gold melts into liquid, growing from tender to firm. It shifts from white to yellow, called the Yellow Chariot. Yellow is the central color; the chariot is the image of earth. Gold possesses dry *qi*, but when met with fire, its dryness vanishes, hardness transforming into softness, hardness and softness as one. Yin and yang intermingle, returning to the ground of central equilibrium—this is called the Yellow Chariot, also named the Golden Elixir.

The sage refining the great elixir gathers years into months, months into days, days into hours. Through methodical pursuit, within a single two-hour period, the transformations of heaven and earth are seized, the workings of yin and yang and the five phases are seized, the *qi* and destiny of the myriad things are seized. Such an opportunity is rare and fleeting—if off by a hair’s breadth, one misses it by a thousand miles, harming nature and injuring life, gaining only to lose again. At this moment, one must apply great effort in the present, outwardly observing form yet seeing no form, inwardly observing the heart yet finding no heart. Both form and body are forgotten, without smoke or fire, like ash and dust, like dust on a bright window.

To pound and blend them is to transform both hardness and softness, erasing all traces of form. To send them into the Crimson Gate is to remain empty and numinous, illuminating even the most subtle. To seal its junctures firmly, ensuring perfect solidity, means that while the Reverted Elixir forms in an instant, its nurturing requires ten months. The seal must be steadfast and unbroken, ceaseless until the moment the embryo is complete and the spirit whole. The flames below must roar day and night without pause.

chunks.original_text: 自有天然真火，炉中赫赫长红也。 始文使可修者，一时之功，用文火以合丹也。 终竟武乃陈者，十月温养，用武火以炼己也。 候视加谨慎者，候视一气之存亡，谨之慎之，防危虑险也。 审察调寒温者，审察火候之度数，不燥不冷，寒之温之，调和相当也。 周旋十二节，节尽更须亲者，前进阳火，暮运阴符，阴阳符火，周而复始，循环无端，功夫不息。 气索命将绝，休死亡魄魂者，功夫到日，百脉俱息，气血融化，犹如小死。 当此之时，七魄已亡，三魂已死，情性精神，凝结不散，如痴如醉，只有先天一点清阳之气，而法身成矣。 此身名曰金刚不坏之神，又曰清净法身，又日紫金丹。 金丹至紫，赫赫至阳，浑无一点阴气夹杂矣。 噫！ 此丹之大不过一粉一提一刀圭，其神通妙用，能出死入生，能点枯骨复活，能开瞽目复明，服之者立跻圣位。 此下德者，有为之法，无中守有之妙诀。 此节注契文“知自守黑”至“常与人俱”一段之义。 其所注之义，较契文尤为精详，其中火候细微，大露天机。 学者若于此节中打的通彻，则修丹妙用，可得其大半矣。 耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通。 真人潜深渊，浮游守规中。 旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同，为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷。 离炁内营卫，坎乃不用聪，兑合不以谈，希言顺鸿蒙。 三者既关楗，缓体处空房。 委志归虚无，无念以为常。 证难以推移，心专不纵横，寝寐神相抱，觉寤候存亡。 颜色浸以润，骨节益坚强。 排却众阴邪，然后立正阳。 修之不辍休，庶炁云雨行。 淫淫若春泽，液液象解冰，从头流达足，究竟复上升。 往来洞无极，怫怫被容中。 反者道之验，弱者德之柄。 耕耘宿秽污，细微得调畅。 浊者清之路，昏久则昭明。 黄中渐通理，润泽达肌肤。 初正则终修，干立未可持。 一者以掩蔽，世人莫知之。
chunks.translated_text:
There exists a natural true fire, blazing crimson within the furnace. At first, when refinement is possible, the work of a single moment employs gentle fire to conjoin the Elixir. In the end, when martial force is arrayed, the ten months of nurturing employ martial fire to temper the self. Vigilance in observation requires utmost care—watching over the qi’s presence or absence, guarding with caution, ever mindful of peril and risk. Careful regulation of cold and warmth entails examining the fire’s measure, neither parched nor chilled, adjusting warmth and coolness to achieve perfect harmony.

Through the twelve cyclical nodes, each node’s end demands renewed intimacy: advancing with yang fire at dawn, circulating yin tally at dusk, the tally and fire of yin and yang revolving endlessly, ceaseless in their cycle. When qi wanes and life nears its end, when the deathlike trance descends, the work reaches its culmination—all meridians stilled, qi and blood fused and transformed, as though in a minor death. At this moment, the seven po are already gone, the three hun already perished; emotions, nature, spirit, and essence congeal without dispersion, as though in stupor or drunkenness. Only a single point of primordial, pure yang qi remains, and the Dharma-body is complete. This body is called the indestructible vajra spirit, also the pure Dharma-body, or the Purple Gold Elixir. When the Golden Elixir turns purple, it blazes with pure yang, utterly free of even a trace of yin qi.

Alas! This Elixir, though no larger than a speck of powder, a pinch, or a knife’s edge, possesses wondrous spiritual efficacy—able to revive the dead, restore withered bones to life, and open blind eyes to sight. Those who ingest it ascend instantly to sagehood. This is the method of those of lesser virtue, the art of "guarding the existent within the nonexistent." This passage annotates the section of the *Cantong Qi* from "Knowing the self, guarding the dark" to "ever abiding with others." Its exegesis surpasses the original text in precision, revealing the subtlest details of fire timing and openly disclosing the celestial mechanism. Should a practitioner fully penetrate this passage, the greater part of the Elixir’s wondrous workings will be grasped.

The three treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—must be sealed, never opened. The true person lurks in the deep abyss, floating and roaming while guarding the compass’s circle. Turning and curving to perceive and listen, opening and closing in perfect accord, they become the pivot of the self, ceaseless in motion and stillness. Abandoning qi’s internal defense, Kan (Water) no longer relies on hearing; Dui (Lake) unites without speech, uttering few words to follow the primordial chaos. Once the three are bolted shut, the body relaxes in an empty chamber. Surrendering the will to emptiness and nothingness, making non-thought the constant state, attainment becomes unshakable. The mind, single-minded and unscattered, sleeps and wakes with spirit embraced, ever vigilant over presence and absence. The complexion grows increasingly moist, the bones and joints ever stronger. Expelling all yin demons, one then establishes true yang.

Unceasing cultivation brings the qi to flow like clouds and rain, gently descending like spring rain, trickling like melting ice. From head to foot it flows, then ultimately ascends again. Coming and going through the boundless void, it fills the body with a subtle warmth. Reversion is the Dao’s verification; weakness is virtue’s handle. Plowing and weeding the long-accumulated filth, the finest adjustments achieve harmony. The turbid is the path to clarity; prolonged darkness yields radiance. The Yellow Center gradually opens to principle, its moisture reaching the skin. Beginning with rectitude, one persists to the end; standing firm, one must not falter. The One serves to conceal—let the world remain ignorant of it.

chunks.original_text: 内营卫（一本荣卫），不辍休（一本辄休） 上节言有为之功精且详矣。 此节承上节而言无为之要。 无为者，抱元守一之道，乃上德之事。 虽是上德之事，而下德者，还丹到手，命基已固，即与上德者同一行持，自有为而入无为矣。 但守中抱一之德，非是空空无为，其中有保先天、化后天之功，须要万缘俱息，诸尘不染，身心大定，方能济事。 夫身心不定者，皆因耳目口三毒害之耳。 耳听乎声，目视乎色，口发乎言，身随耳目口移之，心由声色言动之。 心动身移，真性不明，虽还丹到手，法身难脱，难免阳极生阴，得而终失之患。 若闭塞三毒，不令发通，三毒可转而为三宝。 不但不能为害，而且能以致福。
chunks.translated_text:
Within, the *yingwei* (or *rongwei* in some editions) remains unceasing (or "ceases intermittently" in some editions). The preceding section spoke in fine and thorough detail of the work of active cultivation. This section continues from the above to expound the essentials of non-action. Non-action is the Dao of embracing the primordial and guarding the One—an affair of supreme virtue. Though it is the affair of supreme virtue, those of lesser virtue, once the Reverted Elixir is in hand and the foundation of life secured, proceed in the same practice as those of supreme virtue, moving from active cultivation into non-action. Yet this guarding of the center and embracing of the One is not empty non-action; within it lies the work of preserving the prenatal and transforming the postnatal. One must still all myriad conditions, remain unstained by the dusts, and attain great stillness of body and mind before success is possible.

If body and mind are not still, it is always because the three poisons of the ears, eyes, and mouth cause harm. The ears listen to sounds, the eyes behold forms, the mouth utters words—body follows where ears, eyes, and mouth lead, and mind is moved by sounds, forms, words, and actions. When mind is stirred and body shifts, true nature remains obscured. Even with the Reverted Elixir in hand, the Dharma-body is hard to liberate, and one cannot escape the peril of yang reaching its extreme and giving rise to yin, of gaining only to lose in the end.

If the three poisons are sealed off and not allowed to manifest, they can be transformed into the Three Treasures. Not only will they no longer cause harm, but they will bring about good fortune.

The Yellow Center gradually opens to principle, its moisture reaching the skin. Beginning with rectitude, one persists to the end; standing firm, one must not falter. The One serves to conceal—let the world remain ignorant of it.

chunks.original_text: 闭塞者，非工家闭目、闭口、塞耳之谓，乃非礼勿视、非礼勿听、非礼勿言之义。 非礼勿视，则视者尽礼，闭其非礼之目也。 非礼勿听，则听者尽礼，闭其非礼之耳也。 非礼勿言，则言者尽礼，闭其非礼之口也。 极之，见色不色而目闭，遇声不声而耳闭，非时不言而口闭。 如能闭塞此等耳目口，则内念不得而生，外物不得而入，身心不动，真人潜于深渊。 无识无知，动静如一，而浮游守规中矣。 规者，所以取圆，圆即中，中即圆也。 守规中，即允执厥中之义。 潜深渊，即惟精惟一之义。 精一执中，身心不动不摇矣。 旋曲以视听者，回光返照，黜聪毁智，收敛精神也。 开阖皆合同者，心死神活，闭邪存诚，勿忘勿助也。 为己之枢辖者，己为私欲，辖枢所以克己也。 动静不竭穷者，或动或静，功夫不间断也。 离气内营卫者，离为火为神。 火动则神狂而忿生，纳于营卫，则惩忿而心火下降，神即定矣。 坎乃不用聪者，坎为水为精，水泛则精摇而欲生。 不用其聪，则窒欲而肾水上潮，精即化矣。 兑为金为情，其性主悦。 金燥而情动，则心悦而泄气。 言者心之声，希言则心静情忘，有真悦而阴阳和，一气浑沦而顺鸿蒙矣。 离、坎、兑三者，统精、气、神为内三宝。 外而耳、目、口闭塞，内而精、气、神安静。 内外三宝，既能关键，则内念不出，外物不入，缓其真人之体，处于空房矣。 缓者不即不离，以逸待劳之意。 空房者，空中有体，非顽空，乃真空。 真空者，空而不空，故下文紧接曰：“委志归虚无，无念以为常”也。 委志是不空，无念则又空。 丹书所谓“只灭动心，不灭照心”者是也。 证难以推移，心专不纵横者，专心而致志也。 寝寐神相抱，觉寤候存亡者，寤寐而不忘也。 如是用功，六根门头无漏。 不但真人法身有养，即后天幻身亦自健壮，颜色浸润，骨节坚强，理有可决。 排却众阴邪，然后立正阳者，群阴化尽，金丹成熟，功夫不到不方圆也。 然后二字，大有深意，古仙云：“一毫阳气不尽不死，一毫阴气不尽不仙。 ”若稍有一点阴气未化，是犹祸根。 虽大道在望，未许我成。 故修道者，必修至于纯阳无阴之地而后已也。 既能排去众邪，正阳立而稳妥，从此加功而不辍休，神清气爽，如云雨之行，解燥除烦，淫淫若春泽，寒气尽化，液液象解冰，积滞顿消。 从头流达足者，从头至尾而细微条理。 究竟复上升者，颠倒逆施，而自卑登高。 往来洞无极者，一气运用，而心坚志远。 怫怫被容中者，万物皆空，而无私无虑。 反者道之验者，能返朴即成道之验也。 弱者德之柄者，能柔弱，即刚强之本也。 果能耕耘历劫之污秽，细调本来之天真，虽始而浊，终而清； 初而昏，久而明。 黄中渐通理，润泽达肌肤，诚之于中，达之于外，根心生色，归于形神俱妙之地。 此节言浅意深，其示验证处，多以幻身为喻。 其实内藏温养法身之诀。 试玩节首“真人潜深渊，浮游守规中”之句，可知是有为之后，而又无为之道。 若仅以炼已测之，殊失仙翁妙意。 真人者，圣胎也，方才炼己，真人犹未现象，如何潜深渊而守规中？ 学者须要知的此节是注契文“内以养己”一段之义。 “耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通，真人潜深渊，浮游守规中”四句，即注契文“内以养己，安静虚无，原本隐明，内照形躯”四句也。
chunks.translated_text:
Sealing off does not mean the alchemist’s closing of eyes, shutting of mouth, or plugging of ears—rather, it signifies "see nothing contrary to propriety, hear nothing contrary to propriety, speak nothing contrary to propriety." To see nothing contrary to propriety is to ensure all that is seen accords with propriety, thus sealing the eyes against impropriety. To hear nothing contrary to propriety is to ensure all that is heard accords with propriety, thus sealing the ears against impropriety. To speak nothing contrary to propriety is to ensure all that is spoken accords with propriety, thus sealing the mouth against impropriety. Pushed to its limit, this means encountering form yet not perceiving it as form, so the eyes are sealed; meeting sound yet not perceiving it as sound, so the ears are sealed; speaking only at the proper time, so the mouth is sealed. If one can thus seal the ears, eyes, and mouth, inner thoughts cannot arise, external objects cannot enter, body and mind remain unmoved, and the True Person lies concealed in the abyss. Without perception or knowledge, in motion and stillness as one, one floats and guards the center of the compass.

The compass is what draws the circle; the circle is the center, and the center is the circle. To guard the center of the compass is to hold fast to the mean. To lie concealed in the abyss is to preserve singleness and oneness. With singleness, oneness, and the holding of the mean, body and mind remain unmoved and unshaken. To turn the senses inward in observation is to revert the light and reflect, to dismiss cleverness and destroy cunning, to gather and refine the spirit. That opening and closing are in harmony means the heart is dead yet the spirit lives, the false is sealed and sincerity preserved, neither forgetting nor forcing. The pivot of self-cultivation lies in the self: the self is private desire, and the pivot is what restrains it. That activity and stillness are inexhaustible means that whether in motion or at rest, the work is unceasing.

To separate *qi* from internal defense is to recognize *li* (Fire) as spirit. When fire stirs, the spirit becomes wild and anger arises; when it is received into the defensive and constructive *qi*, anger is curbed, the heart’s fire descends, and the spirit is stabilized. *Kan* (Water) is where hearing is not employed, for *kan* is water and essence. When water overflows, essence wavers and desire arises; if hearing is not employed, desire is blocked, kidney water rises, and essence is transformed. *Dui* (Lake) is metal and emotion, its nature being joy. When metal is dry, emotion stirs, the heart delights, and *qi* is dissipated. Speech is the voice of the heart; to speak sparingly is to still the heart and forget emotion, to find true joy and harmonize yin and yang, so that the *qi* becomes one and flows smoothly through the primordial chaos.

*Li*, *kan*, and *dui* govern the Three Treasures within—essence, *qi*, and spirit. Externally, the ears, eyes, and mouth are sealed; internally, essence, *qi*, and spirit are at peace. When the Three Treasures within and without are thus secured, inner thoughts do not leak out, external objects do not enter, and the True Person’s body is at ease, dwelling in the empty chamber. To be at ease is to be neither attached nor detached, awaiting labor in leisure. The empty chamber is emptiness with substance, not dead emptiness but true emptiness. True emptiness is empty yet not empty, which is why the text immediately follows with: “Entrust the will to emptiness and nothingness, taking absence of thought as the constant.”

Entrusting the will is not emptiness; absence of thought is emptiness. This is what the alchemical texts mean by “only extinguishing the moving heart, not extinguishing the illuminating heart.” The proof is not to be shifted; the heart is focused and not scattered. In sleep, the spirit embraces its counterpart; in waking, one attends to presence and absence—this is to remain mindful whether awake or asleep. Through such practice, the six sense gates are free from leakage. Not only is the True Person’s Dharma-body nourished, but the postnatal illusory body also becomes robust, the complexion moist and radiant, the bones and joints firm and strong—this principle is certain.

Only after dispelling the host of yin evils can the true yang be established. When the multitude of yin is transformed and the Golden Elixir ripens, the work is not yet complete until it is perfected. The word “then” carries profound meaning. The ancient immortals said: “If even a trace of yang *qi* remains, one does not die; if even a trace of yin *qi* remains, one does not become immortal.” If the slightest yin *qi* remains untransformed, it is still a root of misfortune. Though the Great Dao is in sight, one is not yet permitted to attain it. Thus, the cultivator must refine the practice until reaching the state of pure yang without yin.

Once the host of evils is dispelled and true yang is firmly established, one continues to add effort without ceasing. The spirit becomes clear and the *qi* fresh, moving like clouds and rain, relieving dryness and dispelling vexation, gently as spring rain. Cold *qi* is entirely transformed, flowing like melting ice, and accumulated stagnation is suddenly dissolved. From the head, it flows down to the feet—from beginning to end, in fine and orderly detail. Ultimately, it ascends again, reversing the flow from low to high. Coming and going, it penetrates the boundless—one *qi* in motion, the heart resolute and the will far-reaching. All is embraced within, free from self and care. Reversion is the proof of the Dao; weakness is the handle of virtue. If one can truly plow through the filth of kalpas, carefully nurturing the original celestial truth, though one may begin turbid, one ends clear; though one may start dim, one becomes bright.

The Yellow Center gradually connects with principle, moisture reaches the skin, sincerity within manifests without, the root of the heart generates color, and one returns to the realm where form and spirit are both wondrous. This passage appears simple but carries deep meaning, illustrating verification largely through the illusory body. In truth, it conceals the secret of nurturing the Dharma-body. Consider the opening lines: “The True Person lies concealed in the abyss, floating and guarding the center of the compass”—this reveals the Dao of non-action following action. To measure it merely by refining the self would miss the sublime intent of the immortal elder.

The True Person is the sacred embryo. When one has only just begun refining the self, the True Person has yet to appear—how then could it lie concealed in the abyss and guard the center of the compass? The scholar must understand that this passage annotates the line in the *Cantong Qi*: “Nurture the self within.” The four lines—“The ears, eyes, and mouth as the Three Treasures, sealed and not allowed to flow; the True Person lies concealed in the abyss, floating and guarding the center of the compass”—correspond to the four lines in the *Cantong Qi*: “Nurture the self within, abide in stillness and emptiness; the original root is hidden and bright, inwardly illuminating the body.”
chunks.overlap_context:
by sounds, forms, words, and actions. When mind is stirred and body shifts, true nature remains obscured. Even with the Reverted Elixir in hand, the Dharma-body is hard to liberate, and one cannot escape the peril of yang reaching its extreme and giving rise to yin, of gaining only to lose in the end.

If the three poisons are sealed off and not allowed to manifest, they can be transformed into the Three Treasures. Not only will they no longer cause harm, but they will bring about good fortune.

chunks.original_text: 自“旋曲以视听”，至“然后立正阳”二十句，即注“三光陆沉，温养子珠”二句也。 自“修之不辍休”至“细微得调畅”十二句，即注“勤而行之，夙夜不休”也。 自“浊者清之路”至“润泽达肌肤”四句，即注“伏食三载”至“长乐无忧”六句也。 至于契文“道成德就”云云六句，显而易会，故不及之。 可知此节是修命之后，而又修性之事。 结尾指出“初正则终修，斡立末可持”，而愈晓然矣。 初正斡立者，始而有作以修命也。 终修末持者，末而无为以了性也。 性命必须双修，功夫还要两段。 上德者，不待修命而即修性，行此段功夫，便可了却大事。 下德者，必先修命而后修性，命实到手，再行此段功夫，方入圣基。 故曰“初正则终修，斡立末可持”也。 但上德者无为，下德者有为，须要知的先天真一之气。 盖上德者无为，抱元守一，即守此一气也； 下德者有为，后天中返先天，即返此一气也。 若不知上德者无为，便落于空寂，不知下德者有为，便执于幻相。 有为也不是，无为也不是。 所谓知其一万事毕者，正为此耳。 修道者若不遇明师，此一气掩蔽于后天之中，隐而不见，如何能知？ 故曰“一者以掩蔽，世人莫知之”。 学者可不急求真师乎？ 《参同契》笺注直指下篇 东汉徐景休真人撰 栖云山悟元子刘一明解
chunks.translated_text:
From "Turning the gaze inward to refine perception" through "thereafter establishing the True Yang"—these twenty lines annotate the two lines in the *Cantong Qi*: "The Three Lights sink into obscurity, warming and nurturing the child-pearl." From "Cultivate this without cease" through "subtle harmony attained in smoothness"—these twelve lines annotate the passage: "Diligently practice this, day and night without rest." From "The path of turbidity clarified" through "moisture penetrating to the skin"—these four lines annotate the six lines from "Refining through ingestion for three years" to "abiding in joy without sorrow."

As for the six lines in the *Cantong Qi* beginning with "The Dao accomplished, virtue perfected," their meaning is self-evident and thus not expounded here. From this, one may discern that this section concerns the cultivation of *xing* (nature) following the cultivation of *ming* (life). The closing lines—"At first rectify, then refine to the end; the pivot established, the final grasp may be held"—make this ever clearer.

"At first rectify, the pivot established" refers to the initial effortful cultivation of *ming*. "Then refine to the end, the final grasp held" refers to the later effortless completion of *xing*. *Xing* and *ming* must be cultivated together, yet the work proceeds in two stages. Those of superior virtue do not wait to cultivate *ming* before cultivating *xing*; practicing this stage of work, they may resolve the great matter. Those of lesser virtue must first cultivate *ming* and only afterward *xing*; once *ming* is truly attained, they may proceed with this stage of work to enter the sacred foundation. Thus it is said: "At first rectify, then refine to the end; the pivot established, the final grasp may be held."

Yet those of superior virtue practice *wuwei* (non-action), while those of lesser virtue practice *youwei* (action). One must comprehend the primordial True Unity of *qi*. Those of superior virtue, practicing *wuwei*, embrace the origin and guard the One—this is guarding that single *qi*. Those of lesser virtue, practicing *youwei*, return from the postnatal to the prenatal—this is returning to that single *qi*. If one does not understand that those of superior virtue practice *wuwei*, one falls into emptiness and quiescence; if one does not understand that those of lesser virtue practice *youwei*, one clings to illusory phenomena. Neither *youwei* nor *wuwei* suffices alone. The saying "Know the One, and all things are complete" precisely refers to this.

If a cultivator of the Dao does not encounter an enlightened teacher, this single *qi* remains concealed within the postnatal, hidden and unseen—how then could one come to know it? Thus it is said: "The One is concealed, and the world does not know it." How can the scholar not urgently seek a true teacher?

*Commentary and Direct Pointers to the Lower Scroll of the Cantong Qi*
Composed by Xu Jingxiu, Perfected of the Eastern Han
Explained by Liu Yiming, the Awakened One of Mount Qiyun

chunks.original_text: 推演五行数，较约而不繁。 举水以激火，奄然灭光明。 日月相薄蚀，常在朔望间。 水盛坎侵阳，火衰离昼昏。 阴阳相饮食，交感道自然。 名者以定情，字者以性言。 金来归性初，乃得称还丹。 吾不敢虚说，仿效圣人文。 古记题龙虎，黄帝美金华。 淮南炼秋石，玉阳加黄芽。 贤者能持行，不肖毋与俱。 古今道由一，对谈吐所谋。 学者加勉力，留念深思维。 至要言甚露，昭昭不我欺。 金丹之道，阴阳调和之道也。 阴阳和则生丹，阴阳背则败道。 推演五行生克之数，而即知金丹之道，至约而不繁也。 比如举水激火而火灭，水克于火也。 日在朔而蚀，阴盛于阳也； 月在望而薄，阳盛于阴也。 又如月体水盛而阳光亏，日色火衰而白昼昏，凡此皆阴阳偏孤两不相济之象。 若阴阳相应，随时交感，道出自然，有何侵伤乎？ 人之真性属阳，真情属阴。 本来阴阳一气，性情相合，浑然天理。 不识不知，顺帝之则。 不识不知者，性之体也。 顺帝之则者，情之用也。 性情自然，皆出无心。 此两者，同出而异名，如名之有字。 名以定情，情比名也； 字以性言，性比字也。 名字总称一物，性情岂有两件？ 因交后天，真中有假，阴阳分离，性情相背，彼此不和。 如水盛坎侵阳，火衰离尽昏，真情变为假情，真性变为假性矣。 金丹之道，推情合性，假中寻真，杀中求生，使阴阳相合，仍还当年浑然天理，不识不知，顺帝之则之本来面目，称之曰还丹。 还丹者，还其本来原有之物，而非有增有减，又曰还原返本。 吾不敢虚说，仿效圣人文者，是仙翁自叙所注，系有本之谈，而非无稽之语。 这个还丹，古来圣贤，方便立名，等等不一。 古记称曰“龙虎丹”，黄帝称曰“美金毕”，淮南称曰“秋石”，玉阳称曰“黄芽”，《参同》称曰“金砂”，曰“刀圭”。 总以形容还丹一物耳。 此道也，上士闻之，勤而行之，故曰贤者能持行。 下士闻之，大笑去之，故曰不肖毋与俱。 何为古今道由一，对谈吐所谋？ 夫金丹大道，乃历代圣贤口口相传，心心相授，彼此对谈，吐其所谋，乃是真知所见之学问，非妄猜私议可比。 虽成道有先后，而修持则准一，即如《参同》之理。 魏、徐二翁，同学于阴真人，其所着所往，魏证之于徐，徐证之于魏，皆对谈吐谋，岂有虚谬？ 学者若能勉力思维，忽的得其要领，涌身钻入理窟，犹如仙翁对谈所谋，勤而行之，决定成道，则仙翁昭昭不我欺矣。 奈之何世之愚徒，以《参同》目为烧炼凡砂凡汞之事，负却仙翁当年着书婆心，便为毁谤圣道，真地狱种子，而不知悔悟，尚自称修真之士，岂不愧死？ 此节注契文“惟昔圣贤”一段之义。 胡粉投火中，色坏还为铅。 冰雪得温汤，解释成太玄。 金以砂为主，禀和于水银。 变化由其真，终始自相因。 欲作伏食仙，宜以同类者。 植禾当以谷，覆鸡用其卵。 以类辅自然，物成易陶冶。 鱼目岂为珠？ 蓬蒿不成槚。 类同者相从，事乖不成宝。 燕雀不生凤，狐兔不乳马。 水流不炎上，火动不润下。 世间多学士，高妙负良材。 邂逅不遭遇，耗火亡资财。 据按依文说，妄以意为之。 端绪无因缘，度量失操持。
chunks.translated_text:
Expounding the numbers of the Five Phases, it is concise and not cumbersome. Taking water to extinguish fire, suddenly the light is gone. Sun and moon mutually eclipse, always at the new and full moons. When water flourishes, Kan encroaches upon yang; when fire wanes, Li’s daylight dims. Yin and yang consume each other, their interaction the natural Dao. Names define emotions, while characters express nature. When metal returns to the origin of nature, it is called the Returned Elixir. I dare not speak idly, but emulate the writings of the sages.

Ancient records call it "Dragon-Tiger Elixir," the Yellow Emperor praises it as "Radiant Golden Flower," Huainan refines it as "Autumn Stone," Yuyang adds "Yellow Sprout," and the *Cantong Qi* names it "Golden Sand" or "Knife’s Edge." All describe the same Returned Elixir. The worthy can uphold and practice it; the unworthy should not be included. The Dao of past and present is one, spoken in mutual discourse. Scholars must exert effort and reflect deeply. The essential words are utterly plain, shining clearly without deceiving me.

The Dao of the Golden Elixir is the Dao of harmonizing yin and yang. When yin and yang harmonize, the Elixir is born; when they oppose, the Dao is ruined. By expounding the numbers of the Five Phases’ mutual generation and restriction, one immediately grasps the Dao of the Golden Elixir—most concise and not cumbersome. For example, taking water to extinguish fire is water restraining fire. The sun is eclipsed at the new moon when yin prevails over yang; the moon is obscured at the full moon when yang prevails over yin. Again, when the moon’s body is water-flourishing, yang’s light wanes; when the sun’s fire declines, daylight dims—all these are signs of yin and yang being isolated and failing to aid each other. If yin and yang respond to each other, interacting in due time, the Dao arises naturally—how could there be harm?

Man’s true nature belongs to yang, true emotion to yin. Originally, yin and yang are one *qi*, nature and emotion united, perfectly embodying Heaven’s principle. Unknowing and unperceiving, one follows the Emperor’s rule. Unknowing and unperceiving is the substance of nature; following the Emperor’s rule is the function of emotion. Nature and emotion are natural, both arising from non-intention. These two emerge from the same source but differ in name, like a name and its character. Names define emotions, emotions correspond to names; characters express nature, nature corresponds to characters. Names and characters together denote one thing—how could nature and emotion be two separate entities? Yet after engaging with the postnatal, the true contains the false, yin and yang separate, nature and emotion oppose each other, no longer harmonious. Like water flourishing and Kan encroaching upon yang, or fire waning and Li’s daylight dimming, true emotion becomes false emotion, true nature becomes false nature.

The Dao of the Golden Elixir pushes emotion to unite with nature, seeks the true within the false, life within destruction, so that yin and yang reunite, restoring the original undifferentiated Heavenly principle—unknowing and unperceiving, following the Emperor’s rule—returning to the original face. This is called the Returned Elixir. The Returned Elixir is the return of what was originally possessed, neither increased nor diminished; it is also called returning to the origin and reverting to the root.

"I dare not speak idly, but emulate the writings of the sages"—the Immortal Elder recounts his commentary, which is grounded in truth, not baseless words. This Returned Elixir has been variously named by sages of old for convenience. Ancient records call it "Dragon-Tiger Elixir," the Yellow Emperor calls it "Radiant Golden Flower," Huainan calls it "Autumn Stone," Yuyang calls it "Yellow Sprout," and the *Cantong Qi* calls it "Golden Sand" or "Knife’s Edge." All these describe the same Returned Elixir. This Dao, when heard by the superior person, is diligently practiced—thus the worthy can uphold and practice it. When heard by the inferior person, it is met with great laughter and abandonment—thus the unworthy should not be included.

Why is it said that the Dao of past and present is one, spoken in mutual discourse? The Great Dao of the Golden Elixir has been transmitted from mouth to mouth and heart to heart by sages of successive generations, each discoursing and revealing their insights—this is true knowledge and learning, not reckless conjecture or private opinion. Though attainment may come sooner or later, the method of cultivation remains uniform, as in the principles of the *Cantong Qi*. The two elders, Wei and Xu, studied together under Perfected Yin. Their writings and teachings were mutually verified—Wei confirmed Xu’s, and Xu confirmed Wei’s—all through mutual discourse. How could there be falsehood?

If scholars exert effort in reflection, suddenly grasping the essentials and immersing themselves in the cave of principle, as if discoursing with the Immortal Elder, diligently practicing, they will surely attain the Dao. Then the Immortal Elder’s clarity will not deceive me. Yet how is it that foolish disciples of the world regard the *Cantong Qi* as mere alchemy of common cinnabar and mercury, betraying the Immortal Elder’s compassionate intent in writing, thus slandering the sagely Dao? They are truly seeds of hell, unrepentant, yet still calling themselves cultivators of the truth—are they not ashamed to death? This section annotates the meaning of the *Cantong Qi*’s passage, "Only the sages of old..."

Lead powder cast into fire, its color ruined, returns to lead. Ice and snow melted by warm broth dissolve into the Great Mystery. Gold takes cinnabar as its master, harmonizing with mercury. Transformation arises from its truth, beginning and end mutually dependent. To become an immortal who ingests the elixir, one must use those of the same kind. Planting grain requires grain; hatching chicks requires eggs. Using the same kind aids nature, and things are easily formed. How can fish eyes be pearls? How can fleabane become catalpa? Like attracts like; discordant matters do not yield treasure. Swallows and sparrows do not give birth to phoenixes; foxes and hares do not nurse horses. Water does not flow upward in flames; fire does not moisten downward. In the world, many scholars possess fine talents but fail to encounter the right opportunity, wasting their resources in vain fire. Relying on textual interpretation, they recklessly impose their own ideas. Without proper guidance, their measures and conduct are lost.

chunks.original_text: 捣治羌石胆，云母及矾磁。 硫磺烧豫章，泥汞相炼治。 鼓下五石铜，以之为辅枢。 杂性不同类，安肯同体居。 千举必万败，欲黠反成痴。 侥幸讫不遇，至人独知之。 稚年至白首，中道生狐疑。 背道守迷路，出正入邪蹊。 管窥不广见，难以揆方来。 上节题明金来归性，乃称还丹。 若舍性情，以万般与我非类之物，而欲保命全形，岂有此理？ 且如胡粉，乃黑铅烧成，投火仍化为铅。 冰雪乃寒水所结，得温则解化为水。 朱砂乃水银所变，见火则仍化水银。 黄金加水银为白色，见火则即还其黄。 凡此等类，变化皆由本性之真。 所以始而可以此物化彼，终而可以彼物化此，始终相同，易于为功。 岂有欲作伏食仙，而不用同类之物，能以济事乎？ 伏者，伏藏先天之气，而不妄动之意。 即孟子所谓“我善养吾浩然之气”者是也。 食者以虚求实，腹实之义。 即孟子所谓“其为气也，至大至刚，以直养而无害，则塞于天地之间”者是也。 养浩气至于充塞天地，造化不拘，万物难移，方是伏食。 人秉先天一点浩然正气而成人，必伏食浩然正气而方成道，非伏食一切不类之物也．比如植禾以谷，覆鸡用卵，类辅自然，物即成就，非有相强。 鱼目不成珠，蓬蒿不成槚，燕雀不生凤，狐兔不乳马。 水不炎上，火不润下，情不相同，性不相类，而欲有济，如何能之？ 世间多少学士，自负良材，不求真师。 间闻金丹之说，疑为炉火烧炼，据按古文，妄议私猜，失其操持，耗费资财，锻炼五金八石等物，妄冀服食长生。 殊不知此等杂性之物，与我不类，安能在体常居？ 千举万败，不知悔悟，犹生痴想，自谓侥幸不遇，福分浅薄，至死不悔。 噫！ 此等之辈，忘其本念，中道生疑，出正入邪，而犹自欺欺人，以为有得。 以旁门外道之事，着书立论，以盲引盲，管窥蠡测，何可以揆方来乎？ 此节注契文“河上姹女”一段之义。 金入于猛火，色不夺精光。 自开辟以来，日月不亏明。 金不失其重，日月形如常。 金本从月生，朔旦日受符。 金返归其母，月晦日相包。 隐藏其匡廓，沉沦于洞虚。 金复其故性，威光鼎乃熺。 上节言欲作伏食仙，宜以同类者。 同类者为何物？ 即吾本来所具天良之真性，落于后天，即道心所发真知之情者是也。 此情在五行属于金，丹书皆曰真金。 此金历万劫而不坏，为圣贤之阶梯，仙佛之种子。 欲了性命，舍此真金，别无他术矣。 试观世间凡金，其性至刚，其体最坚，入火则愈炼愈明，所谓真金不怕火烧者是也。 金色之精光，不因猛火所夺，犹如日月之光辉，不因照临所亏者相同。 自开辟以来，万物有生有灭，有存有亡，惟日月其形如常。 金重经久不灭，是金与日月同光明，同长久也。 凡金如是，而真金可知。 夫真金之真知，为无情之情，真空而含妙有，不着于色象有无之形，为阴中之阳，有象于月光，故曰金本从月生也。 金从月生，则金丹之功运，宜效月之盈亏，而进退之。 月本纯阴，映日而生光，光即金之象。 月当朔旦，日来受符，月得日光而孕震，初三一阳现于坤地，是金返归其母也。 土能生金，故坤土为金之母。 金返于母，所谓西南得朋。 自一阳二阳三阳，十五光辉满盈，盈而又亏。 十六一阴胎内，至三十晦，东北丧朋，日包月体，而为纯坤，隐藏匡廓之形，沉沦灭迹，入于洞虚之地矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Grind and refine chalcanthite, mica, and alum-magnetite.
Sulfur burns the camphorwood; mud and mercury refine each other.
Smelt the five-stone copper beneath the bellows, using it as the pivot.
Mixed natures of different kinds—how could they dwell as one body?
A thousand attempts must fail ten thousand times; seeking cleverness only breeds folly.
Fortune never favors the reckless; only the perfected know this truth.
From youth to white-haired age, doubt arises midway.
Turning from the Dao to cling to delusion, stepping from the right path into crooked byways.
Peering through a tube yields no broad vision—how can one gauge what lies ahead?

The preceding section clarifies that *jin* returns to its nature, thus called the Returned Elixir.
If one abandons inherent nature and temperament, using myriad things of unlike kind to preserve life and perfect form—how could this be reasonable?
Take, for example, ceruse: forged from black lead, cast into fire, it reverts to lead.
Ice and snow, congealed from cold water, melt into water when warmed.
Cinnabar, transformed from mercury, reverts to mercury when exposed to fire.
Gold mixed with mercury turns white, but upon heating, regains its yellow hue.
All such transformations arise from the truth of their original nature.
Thus, in the beginning, one thing may transmute another, and in the end, that other may transmute the first—beginning and end align, making success attainable.
How could one seek to become an immortal who ingests the elixir without using things of the same kind to achieve the goal?

*Fu* means to subdue and conceal the primordial qi, preventing reckless movement—
just as Mencius said, *"I am skilled at nourishing my vast, flowing qi."*
*Shi* means to seek substance through emptiness, the meaning of a full belly—
just as Mencius said, *"This qi is supremely great and supremely firm. Nourished with uprightness and unharmed, it fills the space between heaven and earth."*
To cultivate this vast qi until it fills heaven and earth, unbound by creation and unshaken by the myriad things—this is *fu-shi*.
Humans are endowed with a single point of primordial, vast, upright qi to become human;
they must ingest this vast, upright qi to attain the Dao—
not by consuming all manner of unlike things.
For example, planting grain requires grain; hatching chicks requires eggs.
Like aids nature, and things readily take form—no force is needed.
Fish eyes do not become pearls; fleabane does not become catalpa.
Swallows and sparrows do not give birth to phoenixes; foxes and hares do not nurse horses.
Water does not flow upward in flames; fire does not moisten downward.
When natures differ and kinds are unalike, how can one succeed?

In the world, countless scholars, self-assured in their fine talents, do not seek a true teacher.
Hearing rumors of the Golden Elixir, they mistake it for furnace-smelting and fire-refining.
Clinging to ancient texts, they recklessly speculate, losing their bearings and wasting resources,
forging the five metals and eight stones, vainly hoping to ingest them for immortality.
Little do they know these things of mixed nature, unlike themselves, cannot dwell long in the body.
A thousand attempts, ten thousand failures—yet they never repent,
still clinging to delusions, blaming misfortune and shallow destiny, persisting until death.
Alas! Such people forget their original intent, waver midway, stray from the right path into error,
yet deceive themselves and others, claiming attainment.
They write books and establish doctrines on heterodox practices, leading the blind with blindness,
peering through tubes and measuring with gourds—how can they gauge what lies ahead?

This section annotates the meaning of the *"He Shang Chan Nü"* passage in the *Canon of Understanding*:
*"Gold enters fierce fire, its color and luster unmarred.
Since the dawn of time, the sun and moon have never dimmed their light.
Gold does not lose its weight; the sun and moon retain their forms.
Gold is born from the moon; at the new moon, the sun receives its mandate.
Gold returns to its mother; at the moon’s wane, the sun envelops it.
Its frame concealed, it sinks into the cavernous void.
Gold regains its original nature; its majestic radiance makes the crucible glow."*

The preceding section states that to become an immortal who ingests the elixir, one must use things of the same kind.
What, then, are these things of the same kind?
They are the true nature of our original heavenly virtue, fallen into the posterior heaven—
the genuine emotions arising from the Dao-heart’s true knowledge.
In the Five Phases, this emotion pertains to metal; alchemical texts call it *true gold*.
This gold endures through ten thousand kalpas without decay,
serving as the ladder for sages and worthies, the seed of immortals and buddhas.
To complete nature and life, apart from this true gold, there is no other method.

Observe worldly gold: its nature is supremely firm, its body most unyielding.
Refined in fire, it grows ever brighter—so-called *"true gold fears no fire."*
The radiant luster of gold is not stolen by fierce fire,
just as the brilliance of the sun and moon is never diminished by their illumination.
Since the dawn of time, the myriad things arise and perish, endure and vanish,
yet the sun and moon retain their forms.
Gold’s weight endures without decay—thus gold shares the same luminosity and longevity as the sun and moon.
If common gold is thus, how much more so true gold?

The true knowledge of true gold is the emotionless emotion, true emptiness containing wondrous existence,
unattached to the forms of color, image, being, or non-being.
It is yang within yin, symbolized by moonlight—hence *"gold is born from the moon."*
Since gold is born from the moon, the workings of the Golden Elixir should emulate the moon’s waxing and waning, advancing and retreating.
The moon is pure yin, reflecting the sun to generate light—light is the image of gold.
At the new moon, the sun receives its mandate; the moon, receiving sunlight, conceives *zhen*.
On the third day, one yang appears in the *kun* earth—this is gold returning to its mother.
Earth generates metal, so *kun* earth is the mother of gold.
Gold’s return to its mother is called *"finding a friend in the southwest."*
From one yang to two yangs to three yangs, by the fifteenth day, its radiance is full.
Full, it then wanes: on the sixteenth, one yin gestates within.
By the thirtieth day, the moon’s wane, it loses its friend in the northeast.
The sun envelops the moon’s body, becoming pure *kun*,
its frame concealed, its traces extinguished, sinking into the cavernous void.

chunks.original_text: 比之修道者，虚极静笃之中，真知灵知合一，忽有一点真灵之光发现。 其光名曰神明，又谓黑中白，又谓水中金，又谓先天真一之气。 如月借日光，一阳生于坤地也，由微而着，光辉圆满，真灵常存。 又用十月温养之功，防危虑险，收敛精神，不露圭角，隐藏沉沦，归于无何有之乡。 亦如月光晦而无迹，日月相抱如一矣。 金复其故性者，真知之情与灵知之性，混而相合，情归于性，性定情忘，不识不知，顺帝之则，金还其元矣。 威光鼎乃熺者，熺为火色。 当情归于性，性恋其情，情即性，性即请，良知良能，寂然不动，感而遂通，灵知不昧，火返其本矣。 金还元，火返本，金火同宫，药即是火，火即是药，炉中赫赫长红，是谓威光鼎乃熺。 鼎而曰光，虚灵之鼎； 光而曰威，刚健之光。 刚健虚灵，有气无质，万物难伤，真金复于本性也。 此节注契文“太阳流珠”至“凝而至坚”一段之义。 火记不虚作，演易以明之。 偃月法炉鼎，白虎为熬枢。 汞日为流珠，青龙与之俱。 举东以合西，魂魄自相拘。 上弦兑数八，下玄艮亦八。 两弦合其精，乾坤体乃成。 二八应一斤，易道正不倾。 上节育金火同宫，金复其本性矣。 然金复其本性者，是阴符之运用。 若功夫不到，不能方圆也。 火记不虚作，演《易》以明之者，火实无火，托阴阳相和之气以为火。 然阴阳有盈虚消长之节，此圣人火记之所以作也。 其作非悬虚之语，乃准诸《易》卦爻象吉凶悔吝以立言。 《易》之坎卦象月，月属水，月在西南纯阴之下，微阳吐露，名曰水中金，其光偃仰，故谓偃月。 此阳进阴消之机，故取象偃月为炉鼎，非取坎为炉鼎。 偃月之光，从西而生，故取象为金，为白虎，在人为情。 金生水，虎能咥人，为妄情； 水生金，虎能护人，为真情。 真情发现，水不泛滥而归原。 则真精生。 故白虎真情，为熬炼真水之枢纽。 所谓五行颠倒用，虎向水中生也。 《易》之离卦象日，日属火，象流珠。 火生于木，火中具有木气，取象为青龙，在人为性。 木生火，龙能伤人，为气性； 火生木，龙能生人，为真性。 真性发现，火不生焰而返本，故日青龙与之俱。 五行不顺行，龙从火里出也。 龙性属阳为魂，虎情属阴为魄，水中生金，火中生木，真情真性相会，魂魄自相拘束，两而不离矣。 魂魄相拘，阴中有阳，如坎，如月上弦之金八两； 阳中有阴，如离，如月下弦之水半斤。 刚柔俱归中正，金水相停，水火相济，真性真情，两弦之气，合而为一，复于乾刚坤柔，易简良知良能之本体，与天为徒，与地为配，金丹凝结，命基永固。 此《易》理变化之道，所以为贵而不倾败也。 此节注契文“金华先唱”至“何敢有声”一段之义。 世人好小术，不审道浅深。 弃正从邪径，欲速阏不通。
chunks.translated_text:
In parallel with the cultivator of the Dao:
Within the utmost emptiness and profound stillness, true knowing and numinous knowing merge as one—suddenly, a single spark of true numinous light appears.
This light is called *shenming* (spirit-illumination), also termed "white within black," "gold within water," or the "primordial true unity of qi."
Like the moon borrowing sunlight, one yang arises in *kun* earth, growing from faint to manifest, its radiance becoming full and round, the true numinous ever-present.
Then, through the work of ten months’ nurturing, one guards against danger and contemplates peril, gathering in the spirit, concealing sharp edges, sinking into obscurity, returning to the realm of *wu-he-you* (the land of nothing-whatsoever).
Just as the moon’s light wanes without trace, sun and moon embrace as one.
When gold recovers its original nature, the passions of true knowing and the nature of numinous knowing blend and unite—passion returns to nature, nature stabilizes and passion is forgotten, "not knowing, not recognizing," following the pattern of the Lord.
Thus gold returns to its origin.
The *weiguang* tripod then glows—*xi* is the color of fire.
When passion returns to nature, nature cherishes its passion; passion becomes nature, nature becomes passion.
Innate knowing and innate capacity, utterly still, respond and thus penetrate—numinous knowing remains undimmed, fire returns to its root.
Gold returns to its origin, fire returns to its source; gold and fire share the same chamber.
The elixir is fire, fire is the elixir; within the crucible, a radiant and enduring redness—this is called *weiguang ding nai xi*.
The tripod is called *guang* (light), the tripod of emptiness and numinosity;
*guang* is called *wei* (might), the light of strength and vigor.
Strength and vigor, emptiness and numinosity—having qi but no substance, no thing can harm it, true gold restored to its original nature.
This section annotates the *Cantong qi* passage from *"The sun’s flowing pearl"* to *"congealing to utmost firmness."*

The *Fire Record* is no empty fabrication; it elucidates through the *Yijing*.
The crescent moon models the crucible and tripod; the White Tiger is the pivot of refinement.
Mercury and the sun are the flowing pearl; the Azure Dragon accompanies it.
Raising the east to meet the west, hun and po naturally constrain each other.
The upper crescent, *dui*, numbers eight; the lower, *gen*, also eight.
When the two crescents unite their essence, the body of *qian* and *kun* is complete.
Two eights correspond to one *jin*; the Dao of Change stands upright, unshaken.

The preceding section nurtures gold and fire in the same chamber, gold restored to its original nature.
Yet gold’s return to its original nature is the operation of the *yin talisman*.
If the work is insufficient, it cannot be both square and round.
The *Fire Record* is no empty fabrication; it elucidates through the *Yijing*:
Fire is not mere fire, but relies on the qi of yin and yang in harmony.
Yet yin and yang have their cycles of waxing and waning, growth and decline—this is why the sages composed the *Fire Record*.
Its composition is no groundless speech, but is established in accord with the *Yijing*’s hexagrams and lines, their auspices, regrets, and remorse.
The *Yijing*’s *kan* hexagram images the moon; the moon belongs to water.
Beneath the pure yin of the southwest, a faint yang emerges—this is called "gold within water."
Its light arches and bows, hence the term "crescent moon."
This is the mechanism of yang advancing and yin receding, thus the crescent moon is taken as the model for the crucible and tripod, not *kan* itself as the crucible.
The crescent’s light arises in the west, thus it is taken as the image of gold, of the White Tiger, and in the person, of passion.
Gold generates water; the tiger can devour people—this is deluded passion.
Water generates gold; the tiger can protect people—this is true passion.
When true passion appears, water does not overflow but returns to its source, and true essence is born.
Thus the White Tiger’s true passion is the pivot for refining true water.
This is what is meant by "the five phases used in reverse; the tiger arises within water."

The *Yijing*’s *li* hexagram images the sun; the sun belongs to fire, imaging the flowing pearl.
Fire is born of wood; within fire there is the qi of wood—this is taken as the image of the Azure Dragon, and in the person, of nature.
Wood generates fire; the dragon can harm people—this is temperamental nature.
Fire generates wood; the dragon can give life to people—this is true nature.
When true nature appears, fire does not flare but returns to its root—thus the sun and the Azure Dragon accompany each other.
The five phases do not proceed in order; the dragon emerges from within fire.
The dragon’s nature is yang, the hun; the tiger’s passion is yin, the po.
Gold is born within water, wood within fire; true passion and true nature meet, hun and po naturally constrain each other, inseparable yet two.
Hun and po constrain each other: within yin there is yang, like *kan*, like the eight taels of gold in the moon’s upper crescent;
Within yang there is yin, like *li*, like the half-*jin* of water in the moon’s lower crescent.
Hard and soft both return to the center; gold and water are balanced, water and fire harmonize.
True nature and true passion, the qi of the two crescents, unite as one, returning to the original body of *qian*’s hardness and *kun*’s softness, the simplicity of innate knowing and innate capacity.
One becomes a companion to heaven, a mate to earth; the golden elixir congeals, the foundation of life is eternally secure.
This is the value of the *Yijing*’s principle of transformation, standing firm and unshaken.

This section annotates the *Cantong qi* passage from *"Gold’s radiance sings first"* to *"how dare there be sound?"*

The world favors petty arts, not examining the depth of the Dao.
Abandoning the correct path for deviant byways, they seek speed but find no passage.

The sun envelops the moon’s body, becoming pure *kun*,

chunks.original_text: 犹盲不认杖，聋者听商宫。 投水捕雉兔，登山索鱼龙。 植麦欲获黍，运规以求方。 竭力劳精神，终年无见功。 欲知伏食法，事约而不繁。 上节言调和阴阳，火候必准诸《易》理，方济大事。 若背《易》理，即不是道。 古仙云：“形以道全，命以术延。 ”延命之术，能以窃阴阳，夺造化，转乾坤，运日月，回斗柄，扭气机，位天地，育万物，乃古今来理窟中第一大术。 惟天生智慧之大人，能以行之。 彼一切愚迷小人，不审道之深浅，专好小术，弃正从邪，入于旁门，犹盲不认杖，聋不听音，捕雉兔于水，索鱼龙于山，植麦欲获黍，运规以求方，是皆枉劳精神，空费功力。 彼岂知神仙伏食大法，约而不繁，一时辰内管丹成哉？ 此节注契文“不得其理”至“与道乖戾”一段之义。 子午数合三，戊己号称五。 三五既和谐，八石正纲纪。 呼吸相含育，伫息为夫妇。 黄土金之父，流珠水之子。 水以土为鬼，土镇水不起。 朱雀为火精，执平调胜负。 水盛火消灭，俱死归厚土。 三性即合会，本性共宗祖。 上节提出伏食之法，约而不繁。 其法为何法？ 即调和五行，混而为一之法也。 子属坎，坎为水； 午属离，离为火。 坎纳戊，离纳己。 坎中实，真知也，戊即真知之信； 离中虚，灵知也，己即灵知之信。 坎一离二，数合为三，戊己士居中央，其数称五。 外则取坎填离，以真一之水，而济灵明之火； 内则流戊就己，以刚健之信，而合柔顺之意。 是为三五和谐。 三五既和谐，则先天性情精神，而统后天精神魂魄，则八卦阴阳定位，而造化纲纪正矣。 八石者，八卦之象也。 阳为纲，阴为纪。 坎离者，八卦之用。 坎离和谐，其余六卦，阴阳俱皆相随而和谐，各得其正矣。 纲纪既立，一动而为呼，呼则生阳； 一静而为吸，吸则生阴。 一阴一阳，动静相关，呼吸相通，彼此含育，情性和合，伫息而为夫妇。 先天之气，自虚无中来，凝而为一黍之珠矣。 以上注契文“丹砂木精”至“都归戊已”一段之义。 水火土三者，俱是道中之要物。 三者合，则生丹生圣，而复先天。 三者离，则生人生物，而落后天。 盖土能生金，水能生木。 土生金，故黄，土为金之父。 水生木，故流珠为水之子。 土何以能生金？ 用离己虚灵之真意，去克坎地混离之浊水，以求真知之金情，故土镇水不起也。 水何以能生木？ 用坎中精一之真水，去克离宫烈焰之燥火，以全灵知之木性。 故水盛火消灭也。 所可异者，水以灭火，何可土镇？ 火调胜负，何可水灭？ 特以水有混杂之水，有精一之水。 火有烈焰之火，有温和之火。 土镇之水，乃混杂之水； 水灭之火，乃烈焰之火。 混杂之水涸，精一之水生； 烈焰之火息，温和之火现。 俱死归厚土者，土镇水，水干而泥成土； 水灭火，火灭而灰化土。 相生相克，克中有生。 真知灵知相合，真情真性同气，刚柔俱归中正，如乌兔会于黄道。 药即是火，火即是药，水火土三姓一家，结为一粒黍米金丹，而共宗祖矣。 阴阳相合，始谓共宗祖。 若不到阴阳相合处，犹有偏孤，未是浑然一气景象，不得谓共宗祖。 正契文“含元虚危，播精于子”之奥义。 虚危，乃阴阳交会之处，亦日月合符行中之处，故有元精在焉。 元精者，金丹之别名，亦即宗祖之谓。

Still blind and refusing the staff, the deaf strain to hear the *shang* note.
They cast nets in water to catch pheasants and hares, scale mountains to seek fish and dragons.
They plant wheat hoping for millet, wield compasses to draw squares.
Exhausting spirit and laboring strength, they toil year-round yet see no achievement.
To know the method of *fushi*, the work is simple and not cumbersome.

The preceding section speaks of harmonizing yin and yang, where the fire-timing must be measured by the *Yijing*’s principles to accomplish the great task. Should one turn from the *Yijing*’s principles, it is no longer the Dao. The ancient immortals said: *“Form is preserved by the Dao, life is prolonged by technique.”* The technique of prolonging life—able to steal yin and yang, seize creation’s power, turn *qian* and *kun*, move the sun and moon, reverse the Dipper’s handle, twist the qi’s mechanism, position heaven and earth, and nurture the ten thousand things—is the foremost great art in the treasury of principles from ancient times to the present. Only the heaven-born sage of wisdom can practice it. Those petty, deluded fools, failing to examine the depth of the Dao, favor petty arts, abandon the correct path for deviant byways, and enter side doors. Like the blind refusing the staff, the deaf not hearing sound, they hunt pheasants and hares in water, seek fish and dragons in the mountains, plant wheat hoping for millet, wield compasses to draw squares—all wasting spirit and squandering effort in vain. How could they know the great method of the immortals’ *fushi*, simple and not cumbersome, where within a single *shichen* the elixir is complete?

This section annotates the *Cantong qi* passage from *“Not grasping its principle”* to *“contrary to the Dao.”*

The *zi* and *wu* numbers unite as three, *wu* and *ji* are called five.
When three and five harmonize, the eight stones establish the guiding principle.
Breathing nurtures one another, stillness becomes husband and wife.
Yellow earth is the father of metal, the flowing pearl is the child of water.
Water treats earth as its ghost; earth suppresses water’s rising.
The Vermilion Bird is the essence of fire, holding balance to adjust victory and defeat.
When water prevails, fire is extinguished; both die and return to thick earth.
The three natures unite, their original nature sharing a common ancestor.

The preceding section presents the *fushi* method, simple and not cumbersome. What is this method? It is the method of harmonizing the five phases, blending them into one. *Zi* belongs to *kan*, *kan* is water; *wu* belongs to *li*, *li* is fire. *Kan* receives *wu*, *li* receives *ji*. *Kan* is solid within—true knowing, and *wu* is the token of true knowing. *Li* is empty within—spiritual knowing, and *ji* is the token of spiritual knowing. *Kan* is one, *li* is two; their numbers unite as three. *Wu* and *ji* earth reside in the center, their number called five. Externally, one takes from *kan* to fill *li*, using the true one’s water to aid the numinous brightness of fire. Internally, one flows *wu* to *ji*, using the firm and strong token to unite with the gentle and compliant intent. This is the harmony of three and five. When three and five harmonize, then the prior-heaven nature, passion, spirit, and essence govern the post-heaven spirit, *hun*, and *po*. The eight trigrams’ yin and yang take their proper positions, and creation’s guiding principle is established. The eight stones are the images of the eight trigrams. Yang is the guiding principle, yin the supporting thread. *Kan* and *li* are the function of the eight trigrams. When *kan* and *li* harmonize, the remaining six trigrams all follow in harmony, each attaining its proper place. With the guiding principle established, one movement becomes exhalation, exhalation generates yang; one stillness becomes inhalation, inhalation generates yin. One yin, one yang, movement and stillness interrelate, breathing communicates, nurturing one another, passion and nature harmonize, stillness becomes husband and wife. The prior-heaven qi comes from emptiness and nothingness, congealing into a single grain of pearl.

The above annotates the *Cantong qi* passage from *“Cinnabar and wood essence”* to *“all return to *wu* and *ji*.”*

Water, fire, and earth are all essential elements within the Dao. When the three unite, they generate the elixir and the sage, returning to prior-heaven. When the three separate, they generate humans and things, falling into post-heaven. For earth can generate metal, and water can generate wood. Earth generates metal, thus yellow earth is the father of metal. Water generates wood, thus the flowing pearl is the child of water. How can earth generate metal? By using *li*’s *ji*—the true intent of numinous emptiness—to overcome *kan* earth’s turbid water mixed with *li*, seeking the metal’s true passion of true knowing. Thus earth suppresses water’s rising. How can water generate wood? By using *kan*’s essence—the true one’s pure water—to overcome *li* palace’s scorching flames, preserving the wood-nature of spiritual knowing. Thus when water prevails, fire is extinguished. What is strange is this: water can extinguish fire, so how can earth suppress it? Fire adjusts victory and defeat, so how can water extinguish it? It is because water has both turbid and pure forms, fire has both scorching and gentle forms. The water earth suppresses is turbid water; the fire water extinguishes is scorching fire. When turbid water dries, the pure one’s water is born; when scorching fire ceases, gentle fire appears. “Both die and return to thick earth” means earth suppresses water, water dries and mud becomes earth; water extinguishes fire, fire dies and ash turns to earth. Mutual generation and mutual overcoming—within overcoming lies generation. True knowing and spiritual knowing unite, true passion and true nature share qi, hardness and softness both return to the center. Like the crow and hare meeting on the yellow path, medicine is fire, fire is medicine. Water, fire, and earth—three surnames in one family—congeal into a single grain of millet-like golden elixir, sharing a common ancestor. Only when yin and yang unite can they be said to share a common ancestor. If they do not reach the point of yin-yang union, there remains bias and solitude, not yet the scene of a thoroughly blended qi, and they cannot be said to share a common ancestor.

This is the profound meaning of the *Cantong qi*’s *“Embracing the primal in *xu* and *wei*, sowing essence in *zi*.”* *Xu* and *wei* are the place of yin-yang union, also where the sun and moon’s paths converge, thus containing primal essence. Primal essence is another name for the golden elixir, also called the common ancestor.

chunks.original_text: 以上注契文“刚柔迭兴”至“播精于子”一段之义。 巨胜尚延年，还丹可入口。 金性不败朽，故为万物宝。 术士伏食之，寿命得长久。 土游于四季，守界定规矩。 金砂入五内，雾散若风雨。 熏烝达四肢，颜色悦泽好。 发白皆变黑，齿落生旧所。 老翁复壮丁，耆妪成姹女。 改形免世厄，号之曰真人。 金丹之道，一得永得，至灵至神，立竿见影，知之者直登彼岸。 奈何世人多不信心，以为世间必无此事。 试思巨胜，乃后天有形滓质之物，人久服之，亦能延年。 而况金丹为先天至宝，修成入腹，岂有不能长生者乎？ 凡金其性坚刚，尚能经久不败，为万物之宝，真金其气纯阳，岂有伏食而不能成仙者乎？ 土出于四季，而四时八节，各循规矩，自然流行不息。 人服金砂而四肢百体，变形易色，自能脱灾免厄。 若有志士，得师口诀，自有为而入无为，了性了命，形神俱妙，与道合真，号曰真人，寿与天齐。 至于四肢坚固，颜色悦泽，发白转黑，齿落重生，犹其余事耳。 此节注契文“如审遭逢”一段之义。 仙翁笺注三篇，体贴伯阳之意，发《参同》所未发。 其中药物火候，无一不在。 但恐人无肯心，无大福分，自不能见真。 序云：“惟晓大象，必得长生。 ”仙翁岂欺我哉？ 三相类原序 参同契者，敷陈梗概，不能纯一，泛滥而说，纤微未备，阙略仿佛。 今更撰录，补塞遗脱。 润色幽深，钩援相逮，旨意等齐，所趋不悖，故复作此，命三相类。 大易性情，各如其度。 黄老用究，较而可御。 炉火之事，真有所据。 三道由一，俱出径路。 枝茎花叶，果实垂布，正在根株，不失其素。 诚心所言，审而不误。 参同契直指三相类上篇 东汉叔通淳于真人撰 栖云山悟元子刘一明解 三相者，一相大《易》性情，一相黄老之术，一相炉火之事。 三道由一，故名三相类。 类者，亦契合之义。 上篇 法象莫大乎天地兮，玄沟数万里。 河鼓临星纪兮，人民皆惊骇。 昝影妄前却兮，九年被凶咎。 皇上览视之兮，王者退自改。 关键有低昂兮，害气遂奔走。 江河之枯竭兮，水流注于海。 金丹之道，最幽最深，至神至妙，暗合乾坤，默通造化，能以有形入无形，以无象生有象。 故古来仙真，上观天符，下察地理，窃阴阳，夺造化，保命全形，完成大道也。 仙翁首以天地示法象者，盖以大道无形，而天地有象，即有以形无，即实以示虚。 而虚无之道，昭昭乎见于象矣。 象者，比象，言此物象彼物也。 法者，效法。 法象者，效法此象也。 天地之象，至大至显，易见易知。 试观天地悬隔，不知几万余里，地下之吉凶未起，而天上之变象已垂。 上天之气运稍错，而地下之悔吝即至。 何以故？ 此感彼应，形相隔而气相通也。 玄沟者，天下地上中空之处。 以其阔大无边，玄渺难测，故为玄沟。 河鼓星纪，皆星名。 河鼓临于星纪之位，是不循度数； 日之昝影，妄有前却，是失其正道。 二者皆反其常。 反常，则水旱灾生，兵疫祸患之凶咎，未有不至者。 故皇王见其象，而退居悔过，以挽天心。 比之人生之初，性情纯一，阴阳和合，及至二八，养为纯阳之体，是谓上德之人。 当此之时，苟非天纵之圣贤，而能保此一点真阳之气者，有几人哉！ 一切世人，俱顺行造化，阳极生阴，阴一生而先天变为后天。

The above annotates the meaning of the *Cantong qi*’s passage from *“Hard and soft alternate in rise”* to *“sowing essence in *zi*.”* Sesame indeed prolongs life, and the returned elixir may be ingested. Gold’s nature does not decay, thus it is the treasure of all things. Alchemists refine and consume it, attaining long-lasting life. Earth travels through the four seasons, guarding boundaries and setting rules. Golden sand enters the five viscera, dispersing like mist in wind and rain. Steaming and fuming reach the four limbs, complexion becomes radiant and fair. White hair all turns black, fallen teeth regrow in their original place. The old man regains youthful vigor, the aged woman becomes a maiden. Transforming form to escape worldly calamities, one is called a *zhenren*. The Way of the golden elixir, once attained, is eternally possessed—most numinous, most divine, its effects immediate as a shadow follows the pole. Those who know it ascend directly to the other shore. Yet how is it that most people lack faith, believing such things cannot exist in this world? Consider sesame, a postnatal, tangible substance; prolonged consumption also extends life. How much more so the golden elixir, the supreme treasure of the primordial, refined and ingested—how could it not grant immortality? All metals, by nature hard and unyielding, endure without decay, prized as treasures among things. True gold, its *qi* purely yang—how could its refinement and consumption fail to achieve transcendence? Earth emerges in the four seasons, and the four seasons with their eight nodes each follow their rules, circulating naturally without cease. One who consumes golden sand transforms the four limbs and the entire body, altering form and complexion, naturally shedding disasters and evading calamities. If a determined seeker receives the master’s oral instructions, they proceed from *youwei* to *wuwei*, completing both nature and life, uniting form and spirit in wondrous harmony, merging with the Dao in truth—styled a *zhenren*, their lifespan equal to heaven’s. As for the firming of the four limbs, the radiance of complexion, the turning of white hair to black, the regrowth of fallen teeth—these are but incidental matters.

This section annotates the meaning of the *Cantong qi*’s passage *“As if meeting by careful encounter.”* The immortal elder’s commentary on the three chapters aligns with Boyang’s intent, revealing what the *Cantong* left unsaid. Within it, medicinal substances and firing times are all accounted for. Yet one fears that without sincere devotion or great fortune, one cannot perceive the truth. The preface states: *“Only by comprehending the great image can one attain long life.”* Could the immortal elder deceive us?

**Preface to the Three Categories of the *Cantong qi***
The *Cantong qi* expounds its outline but lacks uniformity, its discourse overflowing, its subtleties incomplete, its omissions vague. Now I have compiled and recorded this to fill its gaps, refining its profundities, linking its threads, aligning its purport, ensuring its course remains unerring. Thus, I have composed this, naming it *Three Categories*.

The *Yijing*’s nature and emotions each follow their measure. The teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, when examined, may be applied. The work of the furnace and fire has true basis. The three Ways emerge from one, all proceeding from the same path. Branches, stems, flowers, leaves, and fruits all depend from the root—without losing their essence.

What is sincerely spoken is carefully weighed and without error.

**Direct Pointer to the Three Categories of the *Cantong qi*, First Chapter**
Composed by Chutong Chunyu, the Perfected of the Eastern Han
Annotated by Liu Yiming, the Realized One of Qiyun Mountain

The *Three Categories* refers to one category of the *Yijing*’s nature and emotions, one of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi’s arts, and one of the furnace and fire’s work. The three Ways emerge from one, hence the name *Three Categories*. *Categories* also means *correspondence*.

**First Chapter**
No image is greater than heaven and earth—
The dark gully spans ten thousand *li*.
The River Drum approaches the Star Marker,
And the people all tremble in alarm.
The sundial’s shadow recklessly advances and retreats,
Nine years of misfortune befall them.
The sovereign observes and reflects,
The king retreats and reforms himself.
The key has its rises and falls,
Harmful *qi* flees in haste.
The rivers and streams run dry,
Their waters flowing into the sea.

The Way of the golden elixir is most profound, most abstruse, supremely divine, supremely wondrous—darkly harmonizing with heaven and earth, silently connecting with creation. It can enter the formless from the formed, generate the imageless from the imageless. Thus, from ancient times, the immortals observed celestial omens above, examined earthly principles below, pilfered yin and yang, seized creation, preserved life and completed form, fulfilling the great Dao. The immortal elder first presents heaven and earth as models because the great Dao is formless, while heaven and earth have form—using the formed to reveal the formless, employing the substantial to manifest the insubstantial. Thus, the Way of emptiness and nothingness shines clearly in the image.

*Image* means comparison—this thing resembles that thing. *Model* means emulation. *Modeling the image* means emulating this image. The images of heaven and earth are supremely vast, supremely manifest, easy to see, easy to know. Observe how heaven and earth hang apart, separated by who knows how many ten thousand *li*. Before the auspicious or inauspicious arises below, the celestial omens have already descended. If the celestial *qi* and movements err slightly, earthly regrets and misfortunes immediately follow. Why is this? This responds to that—though form is separate, *qi* is connected.

The *dark gully* is the hollow between heaven and earth. Its vastness is boundless, its depths dark and unfathomable, hence the *dark gully*. The River Drum and Star Marker are both star names. The River Drum approaching the Star Marker’s position violates the celestial degrees. The sundial’s shadow recklessly advancing and retreating loses its proper course. Both reverse their norms. When norms are reversed, floods and droughts arise, and calamities of war, plague, and misfortune inevitably follow. Thus, the sage-king, seeing these omens, retreats to repent, seeking to restore the celestial heart.

This is likened to the beginning of human life, when nature and emotions are pure and unified, yin and yang harmonized. By the age of sixteen, one nurtures a body of pure yang—this is called a person of supreme virtue. At this time, unless one is a heaven-endowed sage, how many can preserve this single point of true yang *qi*? All ordinary people follow the course of creation, yang reaching its extreme and generating yin. Once yin arises, the primordial transforms into the postnatal.

chunks.original_text: 阳渐消，阴渐长，恣情纵欲，弃真从假，所谓五行顺行，法界火坑也。 亦如星移本位，日昝妄行，凶咎立至者同也。 若是至人，远取诸物，近取诸身，行金丹有为之道，返本还元。 所谓五行颠倒，大地七宝，如皇王占象御治，鼎新革故，变凶为吉，拔乱反治者同也。 关为门外之铁关，键为门内之木键。 有关键，而盗贼害气自远。 道有关键，而阴魔邪怪自灭。 何则关以防内，键以防外？ 防外者，防其外来之客气； 防内者，防其内生之私欲。 内外严密，则内念不出，外邪不入。 阴渐退，阳渐长，四象可和，五行可攒。 如江河众水，朝宗于海，而不分派横流。 至圣云：“一日克己复礼，天下归仁焉。 ”正关键之妙旨，退改之效征也。 天地之雌雄兮，徘徊子与午。 寅申阴阳祖兮，出入复更始。 循斗而摇光兮，执衡定元纪。 摇光（一本摇招，摇非斗中之星，不能定元纪，应是摇光，今作摇光解） 上言法象取乎天地，则是金丹之道、天地之道也。 天地之道，一阴一阳之道。 天为雄为阳，地为雌为阴。 阳生于子，极于巳； 阴生于午，极于亥。 一日一夜，子午运转，是谓天地之雌雄徘徊于子午也。 夏至日出于寅，入于戌，冬至日出于辰，入于申。 夏至后日渐南，冬至后日渐北，终而复始，是谓寅申阴阳祖，出入复更始也。 摇光，乃北斗之标星，又名天罡星，又名破军星。 天罡所坐者凶，所指者吉。 月建于子，则坐午指子，水旺而火衰； 月建于午，则坐子指午，火旺而水衰。 十二月皆如是坐指，一岁一周天。 北斗第六星为衡星，罡星在前，衡星在后，运四时而行造化，故日循斗而摇光兮，执衡定元纪。 学者若能知的吾身阴阳发生之时，出入之度，扭转罡星，斡回斗柄，则天关在手，地轴由心，因时采药，勤功烹炼，复我先天原本，亦不难也。 但此罡星，人不易知，亦不易见，若非真师指示，谁敢饶舌？ 所谓“日月常加戌，时时见破军。 破军前一位，誓愿不传人”。 罡星一名破军，破军前一位，即所指之方。 所指之方，有先天真一之气，乃生物之祖气。 古来仙真，皆采此一气，而了命了性。
chunks.translated_text:
As yang gradually wanes and yin gradually waxes, one indulges in passions and desires, abandoning the true to follow the false—this is what is meant by the five phases proceeding in their ordinary course, a dharma-realm of fiery pits. It is like stars shifting from their proper positions or the sun recklessly traversing its path, where calamity swiftly arrives.

Yet the perfected person, drawing lessons from afar in things and from near at hand in the body, practices the Dao of the Golden Elixir with effort, returning to the root and reverting to the origin. This is what is meant by the five phases inverted, the seven treasures of the great earth—akin to the sage-king who, observing celestial omens, governs with renewal, transforming misfortune into fortune and restoring order from chaos.

The *guan* is the iron barrier outside the gate; the *jian* is the wooden bolt within. With *guan* and *jian* in place, thieves and harmful *qi* keep their distance. The Dao, too, has its *guan* and *jian*, and thus yin demons and wayward spirits naturally perish. Why so? The *guan* guards within, the *jian* guards without. Guarding without means warding off external guest *qi*; guarding within means restraining internal selfish desires. When inner and outer are strictly secured, inner thoughts do not leak out, and external perils do not enter. Yin gradually recedes, yang gradually grows, the four images may harmonize, and the five phases may gather. Like the myriad waters of rivers and streams all flowing toward the sea, they do not branch into errant currents.

The utmost sage said: *"For a single day, master the self and return to ritual propriety, and all under heaven will turn toward humaneness."* This is precisely the subtle principle of the *guan* and *jian*, the manifest effect of retreat and reform.

The female and male of heaven and earth—
they linger between *zi* and *wu*.
The *yin* and *yang* ancestors of *yin* and *shen*—
they emerge and enter, ever renewing their beginning.

Following the Dipper to sway the *Yaoguang*,
grasping the balance to fix the primordial order.
*(Note: One version reads "yaozhao," but since "yao" is not a star within the Dipper and cannot determine the primordial order, it should be "Yaoguang." Here, it is rendered as Yaoguang.)*

The above speaks of modeling after the celestial and terrestrial patterns—this is the Dao of the Golden Elixir, the Dao of heaven and earth. The Dao of heaven and earth is the Dao of one yin and one yang. Heaven is male and yang; earth is female and yin. Yang arises at *zi* and culminates at *si*; yin arises at *wu* and culminates at *hai*. In a single day and night, *zi* and *wu* revolve—this is the female and male of heaven and earth lingering between *zi* and *wu*. At the summer solstice, the sun rises in *yin* and sets in *xu*; at the winter solstice, it rises in *chen* and sets in *shen*. After the summer solstice, the sun gradually moves south; after the winter solstice, it gradually moves north, cycling endlessly—this is the *yin* and *yang* ancestors of *yin* and *shen*, emerging and entering, ever renewing their beginning.

*Yaoguang* is the pointer star of the Northern Dipper, also called the *Tiangang* star or *Pojun* star. Where the *Tiangang* sits is inauspicious; where it points is auspicious. When the lunar station is at *zi*, it sits at *wu* and points to *zi*, water flourishes and fire wanes; when the lunar station is at *wu*, it sits at *zi* and points to *wu*, fire flourishes and water wanes. For all twelve months, it sits and points thus, completing one celestial cycle in a year. The sixth star of the Northern Dipper is the *Heng* star; the *Gang* star leads, the *Heng* star follows, governing the four seasons and enacting creation. Hence it is said: *"Following the Dipper to sway the Yaoguang, grasping the balance to fix the primordial order."*

If scholars can precisely know the times when yin and yang arise in their own bodies, the degrees of their emergence and entry, and turn the *Gang* star to revolve the Dipper’s handle, then the celestial gate is in hand, the earth’s axis is at heart. By gathering the medicine in accordance with the season, diligently refining and tempering, restoring one’s original prenatal nature is not difficult. Yet this *Gang* star is not easily known or seen; without a true teacher’s guidance, who would dare speak idly?

As the saying goes:
*"The sun and moon constantly reach *xu*,
At all times, the *Pojun* is seen.
The position before *Pojun*—
Vow never to transmit it to others."*

*Pojun* is another name for the *Gang* star; the position before *Pojun* is the direction it points. In that direction lies the primordial true unity of *qi*, the ancestral *qi* that gives life to all things. From ancient times, immortals and perfected beings have all gathered this single *qi* to complete both life and nature.

This is likened to the beginning of human life, when nature and emotions are pure and unified, yin and yang harmonized. By the age of sixteen, one nurtures a body of pure yang—this is called a person of supreme virtue. At this time, unless one is a heaven-endowed sage, how many can preserve this single point of true yang *qi*? All ordinary people follow the course of creation, yang reaching its extreme and generating yin. Once yin arises, the primordial transforms into the postnatal.

chunks.original_text: 所谓得其一万事毕者，即此一气也。 丹经子书，不肯直指罡星为何物，一气在何处者，恐为匪人所得，有遭天遣耳。 悟元子斗胆，今为祖师传真写神，稍露天机。 若有志士见之，心知默会，此乃鬼神所示，非悟元之罪也。 夫吾之真正罡星，不是别物，即道心之真知也。 真知具有先天至阳之气。 此气统阴阳，含五行，为性命之根，道德之源，藏而为真性，发而为真情，性也情也，皆是至真之物。 其分性情者，以动静论之耳。 此气本来原是我家之物，因落后天，假陷其真。 真知有昧，聪明外用，妄念内生，狐朋狗党，真知变为假知，生气化为杀气。 先天之气，不属于我。 如我家之物，走失他家，罡星坐于我，而指于他矣。 今欲返还先天，须要在他家盗来。 盗之之法，杀机中求生机，妄情中求真情。 真情吐而真知现，真知现而回光返照。 罡星指内而不指外，生气收内而不散外，可以和四象，可以攒五行，可以了性命，可以完大道。 但恐人无志气，费不得心思穷理，下不得功夫寻真，不得亲见罡星耳。 噫！ 可与知者道，难与不知者言也。
chunks.translated_text:
The so-called "attaining this one, all matters are complete" refers precisely to this single *qi*. Alchemical classics and philosophical texts dare not directly point to what the *Gang* star is or where this *qi* resides, fearing it might fall into the hands of the unworthy and incur heavenly retribution. This humble one, Wu Yuan, now boldly transmits the true form and spirit of the ancestral teachings, slightly revealing the celestial mechanism. Should any aspirant encounter this and comprehend it inwardly, know that it is shown by spirits and gods—this is no transgression of Wu Yuan.

Now, our true *Gang* star is no other thing but the true knowing of the Dao-heart. This true knowing possesses the primordial, supremely yang *qi*. This *qi* governs yin and yang, embraces the Five Phases, and is the root of nature and life, the source of Dao and virtue. Concealed, it becomes true nature; expressed, it becomes true feeling. Nature and feeling are both utterly real—what distinguishes them is merely movement and stillness. Originally, this *qi* was our own possession, but upon descending into the postnatal realm, its truth became obscured. True knowing dims, cleverness turns outward, and delusive thoughts arise within. Foxes and dogs gather as companions; true knowing becomes false knowing, and life-*qi* transforms into killing-*qi*. The primordial *qi* no longer belongs to us. Like our own property strayed into another’s home, the *Gang* star sits within us yet points elsewhere.

To return to the primordial, one must steal it back from that other home. The method of theft lies in seeking life within killing, truth within delusion. When true feeling is expressed, true knowing appears; when true knowing appears, the light turns inward in reflection. The *Gang* star points within rather than without; life-*qi* is gathered inward rather than scattered outward. Thus one may harmonize the Four Images, amass the Five Phases, complete nature and life, and fulfill the Great Dao. Yet I fear that people lack resolve, unwilling to expend the effort to exhaust principles, to apply the work of seeking truth, or to personally witness the *Gang* star.

Alas! This may be spoken to those who know; it is difficult to convey to those who do not.
